"James is the Roger Federer of Jeopardy, both flesh and not, an otherworldly creature who possesses talents heretofore unknown to humankind (at least on one game show). He is ethereal, floating through the game with peerless grace. Unlike Federer, he does not remind me of my own clumsy body’s all-too-human limitations, because his mastery of the game manifests as pure intellect—the platonic ideal of a trivia brain at work. That is not to say that James has no physical elegance. Quite the contrary. It is cliché to say a player doesn’t break a sweat, but James literally never sweats, and I am, in fact, not convinced he is capable of sweating. He has probably mastered the ability to regulate his own body temperature."

“There are many ways to be “difficult” in this world: stubborn, demanding, inconvenient, complex, troublesome, baffling, illegible. Black womanhood is where they overlap. The funny thing is, I know this because of Toni Morrison. Morrison is difficult. She’s difficult to read. She’s difficult to teach. She’s difficult to interview. Notwithstanding the voluminous train of profiles, reviews, and scholarly analysis that she drags behind her, she’s difficult to write about. But more to the point, she is our only truly canonical black, female writer—and her work is complex. This, it seems, is difficult to swallow.”
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

The blackest cultural event in recent history, known more widely as the premiere weekend for Marvel’s Black Panther, is on the horizon. One of the key driving forces behind the year of enthusiastic anticipation is how Wakanda (the legendary superhero’s origin as king of the fictional African nation) taps directly into the long and rich tradition of black Americans’ fascination with seeing themselves depicted as royalty in pop culture. For decades, black people have been left to wonder what might have been were it not for the ravaging influences of colonialism. From the looks of the red carpet premiere in Los Angeles, Black Panther feels like so much more than a movie. It’s a celebration of why we matter, a window into what could have been.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Read "When We Were Kings and Queens" by @deephunk on Slate.com. Link in bio.

Only the American right has had a consistent, large, and organized faction based on paranoid conspiracism for six decades. Back in 1954, after the Senate (including half of his fellow Republicans) censured Joe McCarthy, the pathogens of his conspiracy madness remained, and a generation ago began seriously propagating and infecting the mainstream, weakening its immunities to a demagogue like Donald Trump. Looking back at that Republican history, it’s clear that the party’s reality-based Establishment was in charge from the 1960s through the ’80s, exploiting but marginalizing its useful idiots. It wasn’t until the age of right-wing talk radio and Fox News and Breitbart that the Establishment lost control, as crackpot habits of mind achieved dominance. Indeed, more and more of the reckless, hysterical conspiracist language of Trump’s frenzied defenders in the mainstream resembles that of the lunatic, fringe right from a half-century ago.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Read more from 'How the GOP Went Crazy' by Kurt Andersen on Slate.com. Link in bio.

Under the cover of his soothing rhetoric about unity and bipartisanship, Trump called on Congress to give him unprecedented and unquestionably antidemocratic powers: “Tonight,” he said, “I call on the congress to empower every Cabinet secretary with the authority to reward good workers—and to remove federal employees who undermine the public trust or fail the American people.”
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
By design, it is easy to overlook the true significance of the second half of that phrase. But dwell on it for a moment, and imagine what this would actually look like in practice. Under Trump’s proposal, any Cabinet secretary could decide that, say, a law enforcement official investigating the president had “undermined the public trust” or “failed the American people”—and fire him on the spot. In other words, Trump is calling for an end to any semblance of independence for the IRS, the FBI, the Department of Justice, or any other federal agency.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Read more from Yascha Mounk on the State of The Union on Slate.com. Link in bio.

"Did he cut his own hair?” An excerpt from Charlie Jane Anders' "The Minnesota Diet", read more on Slate.com. Link in bio. 
Illustration by @lauracallaghanillustration.

2/3 
Charlie Jane Anders' story is different than standard sci-fi tropes around food scarcity.  Rather than imagining climate change–driven crop failures and other environmental disasters, "The Minnesota Diet" portrays a future urbanized world that is, thanks to the technologies we see emerging even today, better insulated from the risks of agricultural disruption—better insulated, that is, right up until it isn't. 
The question of how we balance our farm and food system between large-scale and smaller-scale production is as yet unsettled. But Anders' story gives us insight into a different way of considering the problem. Powerful solutions to problems of both health and sustainability exist already, right now, in our own behaviors.

Excerpt from a response by Christopher Wharton, a food systems and security researcher to Charlie Jane Anders' short story "The Minnesota Diet.” Illustration by @lauracallaghanillustration. 
Read more on Slate.com

"After eight years of a Democratic administration, the new Republican president came in with a lightning-strike agenda.
 He confirmed reliable, career conservatives to the Cabinet and stocked the federal judiciary with young, right-leaning judges. He put a reliable originalist on the Supreme Court, then picked off some low-hanging policy fruit, repealing or mitigating dozens of Obama-era regulations that he said were burdening business. He made repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act and tax reform his two legislative priorities, pushing Congress to strong-arm them through the process. (The first push collapsed in its unpopularity; the second was successful.) Together, the Republican leadership repealed the individual mandate, opened the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling, and paid for a massive tax cut by punishing coastal Democratic enclaves. The new commander in chief declared a new day in foreign policy, which consisted mostly of performative saber-rattling—we don’t apologize for America anymore, and so on—without actually changing much." Read more on Slate.com

One prominent line of conservative response to this weekend's events in Charlottesville, Virginia, has been to admit that murderous white supremacist violence is bad while noting that liberals who engage in "identity politics" are bad too. An editorial about Charlottesville in the Wall Street Journal took time to complain about leftists who "divide Americans by race, ethnicity, gender and even religion" and asserted that "a politics fixated on indelible differences will inevitably lead to resentments that extremists can exploit in ugly ways." Here's a short history of racial categorization in the United States:

1619: African slaves are brought to North America.
1787: The United States Constitution approves the continued existence of black/African slavery.
1857: The Supreme Court rules in the Dred Scott case that "Negroes" cannot be American citizens.
1865: Slavery is outlawed, but many black Americans are subsequently denied the right to vote, among many other rights, often via violence.
1896: The Supreme Court rules in Plessy v. Ferguson that racial segregation is constitutionally permissible.
1960s: Congress finally passes laws ending segregation and guaranteeing black Americans the right to vote.
In short, the first 350 years or so of U.S. history involved white Americans insisting that black Americans were members of an inferior racial group and setting up systems of employment, housing, education, and law enforcement that reflected that belief. The subsequent 50 years have involved whites presuming to be flabbergasted that anyone could think racial identity was a relevant subject in American life. It's a neat trick! (Photo by Zach Gibson/AFP/Getty Images)

On Tuesday, President Trump, hepped up on news that North Korea had successfully miniaturized a nuclear warhead, warned Kim Jong-un that further threats to the United States “will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.” Two days later, speaking to reporters at his New Jersey golf course, the macho commander in chief declared that perhaps his initial statement “wasn’t tough enough”—that something about the combination of “fire” and “fury” and world-historical destruction said Trump is a wuss. Tomorrow, perhaps he will pledge to crisp North Korea as black as a well-prepared steak.

The president’s original boast—described by the New York Times as “improvised”—has been subject to the kind of Talmudic analyses that no Trump outburst deserves. @slate's Katy Waldman compiles six of such reaching expert theories on why the dumb stuff Trump said about North Korea is actually smart, read more on slate.com (Photos by Nicholas Kamm/Getty Images)

On Tuesday, Rep. Jason Chaffetz said that members of Congress ought to get a housing stipend along with their salaries: Maintaining residences in both Washington, D.C., and their home districts, the soon-to-be-erstwhile congressman argued, is simply too expensive on a meager $174,000 salary. Detractors quickly piped up that Chaffetz is the same guy who recently recommended that in order to afford health insurance, all Americans have to do is forgo new iPhones: In terms of financial advice, he’s no Suze Orman. But still, maybe he’s onto something; maybe members of Congress do need a housing solution for when the legislature is in session so they’re not sleeping on cots in their offices, as Chaffetz did. And maybe the answer is right in front of us: We should take inspiration from one of America’s greatest institutions, higher education, and make our representatives live in dorms. Since that 1939 world debut of The Wizard of Oz, millions upon millions of queer kids have identified with the aching melody of “Over the Rainbow,” yearning to close their eyes and wake up somewhere “far, far away, behind the moon, beyond the rain,” a place where “troubles melt like lemon drops.” Like Dorothy, Gilbert Baker was from Kansas. Unlike Dorothy, Baker eventually landed in San Francisco, and became central to a burgeoning queer liberation movement when he made the first official gay pride rainbow flag in 1978. 
As a colorful symbol literally appearing in nature, it lent credence to the affirming notion that sexual minorities were naturally occurring, beautiful variations on a theme, rather than sinful, sick or criminal deviations from the only acceptable norm. It built on the early history of queer life by echoing the brightly colored displays that gays and lesbians used to pin on lapels or tuck into pockets to signal the shape of their hearts. It expressed solidarity with the anti-war and civil rights movements that helped launch queer liberation. It paid homage to Oz. “A flag fit us as a symbol ... We are a people, a tribe if you will. And flags are about proclaiming power.” — Gilbert Baker, 1951-2017, seen above at the Stockholm Pride Parade in 2003. Read more from 'The Quiet Allure of the Rainbow Flag' by Nathaniel Frank on Slate. (📷 Fredrik Persson/AFP/Getty Images)

Consumerism plays a massive role in climate change, and the environmental impact that all of our material goods have on the planet goes far beyond the greenhouse gases emitted in the process of creating and transporting these things. In fact, much of it has to do with what we leave behind. It’s a manmade phenomenon so massive that Earth scientists suggest it’s creating a distinct geological layer upon the Earth made up of technofossils. According to a conservative geological estimate from a team of international researchers led by the University of Leicester, all this stuff weighs 30 trillion tons. That’s 110 pounds—the weight of a semi-truck’s tire—for every square meter of the earth’s surface. The group also calculated that the sheer diversity of the types of technofossils we as a species have made—it already exceeds the number of biotic species living on Earth now, and may even “exceed the total biological diversity through Earth’s history.” Read more from @starrevartan on what we can do to reduce waste and make the technosphere smarter on Slate. 
Above, an 11-year-old girl collects what can be used as food for pigs at a landfill dumpsite outside Siem Reap in Cambodia on March 19, 2015. (📷 Athit Perawongmetha/Reuters)

But I want to have a great health care bill and plan—and we will and it will happen.” Hmm. That doesn’t sound quite right.

The Department of Homeland Security issued a statement Saturday afternoon, after a week of self-inflicted chaos, not to mention moral upheaval, announcing that in order to comply with U.S. District Judge James Robart’s Friday ruling blocking the Trump administration’s de facto Muslim ban, it had “suspended any and all actions implementing the affected sections of the Executive Order.” As Mark Joseph Stern wrote, "[This] decision marks a huge step forward in the ongoing litigation over the executive order. Robart recognized that it is not just the ban’s immediate application to immigrants in transit that violates the Constitution; it is the ban as a whole. Even if the administration were to somehow execute the ban in a way that respects its targets’ due-process rights, it would still run afoul of basic equal protection and First Amendment principles. Simply put, there is no constitutional way to implement an unconstitutional order." (Photo from Thursday's protest against the travel ban, Brooklyn, New York, by @l_l_w)

With its new bike share program, Philadelphia has made a mission of trying to buck the national trend of bike-share users being white, rich, educated, and male. The city has moved bike stations into nonwhite neighborhoods. It’s used ambassadors. It’s hired a multiracial team to run the bike-share program. And it’s tried and abandoned other ideas, in an attempt to break the social stigma of riding a bike in poor neighborhoods. 
This week on Slate’s Placemakers podcast, we visit Philadelphia to explore how the city is making bike share more accessible, and more diverse, two wheels at a time. 
Listen to the full episode here and subscribe on iTunes: http://slate.me/Placemakers11

Everyone has that unrequited love. That person that you’ve pined after, but perhaps have never even met. For mathematician-turned-artist, Sarah Sole (@hillaryporm_official), that person is Hillary Clinton. In 2007, she had a sex dream about Hillary, and it started her on an eight-year internal love story, painting portrait after portrait. Sarah Sole’s work puts Hillary into unique scenarios, much like this image, where she’s portrayed as Tarzan. To listen, subscribe to the new Panoply podcast Why Oh Why in iTunes.

Kanye West’s set at the Meadows Music and Arts Festival in Queens, New York, came to an abrupt end when the rapper received word that his wife, Kim Kardashian West, had been held up at gunpoint in Paris, CNN reports. A spokesperson for Kardashian West told CNN her assailants were “two armed masked men dressed as police officers,” and described her as “badly shaken but physically unharmed.” She was in Paris to attend Fashion Week. Slate’s Aymann Ismail (@aymanndotcom), who was attending the concert and shot the photo above, reported that the mood of the crowd was good despite Kanye’s abrupt exit. “They all got it,” he said.

Chattanooga, Tennessee, has a lightning-fast, publicly run broadband network that has attracted a lot of tech talent to the city. But as the city builds an economy around technology, one thing is becoming apparent: There’s a gaping divide between those who are tech-savvy and those who aren’t. In some neighborhoods, as few as 1 in 5 households have an internet connection. 
So, can Chattanooga bridge its digital divide? This week on Placemakers, the Slate podcast about cities and the people who shape them, we explore one city’s struggle to enhance digital literacy. We’ll visit Tech Goes Home, an organization that’s trying to help low-income students and adults who find it hard to function in a world that’s more dependent on Internet every day. And we’ll find out why Chattanooga’s digital literacy problems are more common than you think.

Listen here: slate.me/placemakers6

“We age just like everybody else ages, but we age in many cases with differences… and we’re concerned that our caregivers aren’t going to understand or accept that.” As an 82-year-old transgender woman, Barbara Satin understands the problems many LBGTQ Americans face as they grow old. Because, well, she's been there. 
As an LGBTQ activist with a history of solving issues of aging and faith, Satin also knows how to help. That’s why she created Spirit on Lake, an affordable-housing community aimed at giving LBGTQ elders a safe place to call home. 
This week on Placemakers, join us as we travel to Minneapolis, Minnesota. We’ll meet Barbara Satin and take a personal tour of Spirit on Lake, only the second such affordable-housing development in the nation. And we’ll learn more about the unique challenges LGBTQ American seniors face in the process. 
It's a special place. You won't want to miss it. 
Listen here: slate.me/placemakers5

Can self-gentrification remake Hunts Point? One entrepreneur says yes. Majora Carter embraces the idea of “self-gentrification” in her native South Bronx. She founded a park in a spot slated to become a waste-transfer facility. She’s hired local gamers to test software and provide customer service for major tech outfits. And now she’s opened the first boutique coffee shop in Hunts Point (pictured above), a marginalized neighborhood that, once upon a time, she swore she would leave forever. 
So what's next? “[O]ur goal is really to export this model,” Carter says. “The South Bronx really is my research and development lab.” This week on Placemakers, we talk to Carter about why she came back to Hunts Point, and what obstacles she faces as she seeks to expand this model outside of Hunts Point. 
Join us! Listen and subscribe here: Slate.com/placemakers

#huntspoint #birchlovesyou

Where can artists go when big cities price them out? How about adorable, struggling towns like Tieton, Washington? Once a sleepy town in decline, a recent influx of artists and artisans has transformed this eastern Washington hamlet, infusing it with new life and activity. But how do the longtime residents feel about it? 
In episode 3 of Placemakers, our new podcast about cities and the people who shape them, we’ll take you to Tieton, and talk to the artists who are helping to bring Tieton back to life. We’ll also take the temperature of longtime residents, many of whom share mixed feelings about the town’s revival. 
Join us! Slate.com/placemakers

In Charles Roux’s ongoing series “Fictitious Feasts,” meals from famous stories aren’t just abstractions but realistic, sumptuous tableaus that can evoke an entire invented world in one imaginatively rendered dining table. Roux even makes all the meals in the photos himself, and almost always eats the food after the shoots—except for some cupcakes he made for his Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland shoot: They looked tasty but weren’t as good as expected. @roux_charles

We’re thrilled to introduce Placemakers, a new Slate podcast about discovery and community. Each week on Placemakers, we criss-cross the country, introducing you to real people in real communities — people who make a difference in how we travel, work, and live. You’ll never look at your community the same way again.

“There are certain dogs, just like people, who, from my perspective, have a deep, expressive nature. Their eyes can have a really soulful quality to them. Those were the dogs I was looking for,” said photographer Nancy LeVine, of her project, Senior Dogs Across America. Over the course of 12 years, she traveled across America, visiting animal sanctuaries, rescue groups, veterinarians, and friends to find elderly dogs to photograph. Above, left to right: Breebee, 21, Nuny, 19, Ralston, Wyoming. @senior_dogs_across_america

“I wanted to do a series that would make people think about how much plastic we use, without being too ‘telling people what to do’ but make people think on their own,” said photographer Vilde Rolfsen of her Plastic Bag Landscapes. “The plastic bag itself is so useless because there are so many other more sustainable alternatives you can use. … That’s why I wanted it to be aesthetically pleasing to look at.” @ellevillewilde

Drinking wine doesn’t just change how you feel—it also changes how you act and how you look. Marcos Alberti’s series “3 Glasses Later” is proof. “If you drink responsibly, surrounded by your friends and in a happy environment, wine is great!” he said. 
Follow Alberti @marcos_alberti #invinoveritas

With the death of Malick Sidibé last week, the world is mourning the loss of a towering figure in the African art world. The 80-year-old photographer was best known for his black-and-white images of the stylish residents of his native Bamako, Mali, as the country transitioned from colonial rule to independence in the 1960s and beyond. Shot in his studio as well as at nightclubs and in the streets, these photos, as the Guardian’s Priya Elan notes, “changed the idea of black beauty in fashion.” “There are many more phenomenal works beyond the iconic images. Malick was a master of the highest order,” Jack Shainman said, of an exhibition at his gallery of Sidibé's lesser-known photographs, including some that have not been exhibited previously, on view through 4/23. Above, 'Les deux amis au cours d'une soirée populaire', 1968-2008. @jackshainman

Using publicly available embedded GPS information, Nate Larson and Marni Shindelman have tracked tweets across the country and beyond, recording the often uncanny ways the virtual realm interacts with the physical one. In 2009, the photographers came across a post showing the location of a geotagged tweet written by someone who’d just been laid off in downtown Chicago. They decided to go there and make a photo of whatever they found. Seeing the mostly empty street scene paired with the tweet was a revelatory moment. “People talk about disconnection in the digital age. This is somehow about re-connection, through that meta layer of information that’s around us all the time. We like to think of it as pulling down bits of the cloud,” Shindelman said. 
Above, Pittsville, Maryland.

Photographer Francesca Cesari breast-fed her son until he was 9 months old. After this time passed, and a friend of hers took a break from their portrait session to breast-feed her baby, Cesari said, “I had the chance to observe the scene with new eyes, keeping a huge amount of empathy and knowledge but also being free of the emotional involvement I had experienced in the past.” 'In the Room' is her ongoing project photographing mothers breast-feeding their babies. “The right image comes from the unexpected,” said Cesari, “and if the picture isn’t always taken in the precise second when the baby gets asleep, but during the process of comforting, embracing or calming down, that equally conveys the message I want to give, because all of that is part of the process.”

Born to a Chinese mother and an American father, Thomas Holton found a greater connection to his Chinese heritage through photographing a family living in New York City’s Chinatown. Holton met the Lam family in 2003, and much like the 350-square-foot apartment in which they lived, he envisioned creating a small-scale documentary about their lives in a tenement building on Ludlow Street. Thirteen years later, Holton’s work has become a book, The Lams of Ludlow Street, published this month by Kehrer Verlag. Above, Family Portrait, 2004. @kehrerverlag

Obama didn’t herald a post-racial America as much as he did a racialized one, where many whites were hyperaware of their racial status. “The election of the country’s first black president had the ironic upshot of opening the door for old-fashioned racism to influence partisan preferences after it was long thought to be a spent force in American politics,” wrote Brown University political scientist Michael Tesler in 2013. Trump speaks to this nostalgic bigotry, signaling—in ways subtle and otherwise—that he plans to “Make America Great Again” by making the white American worker the center of his universe.

Read more from @jbouie's 'How Trump Happened' on Slate.com (link in profile). Photo from "Postcards From America" by Mark Power/Magnum Photos @magnumphotos

It’s not just anger over jobs and immigration. White voters hope Trump will restore the racial hierarchy upended by Barack Obama. Read more from @jbouie's 'How Trump Happened' on Slate.com (link in profile). Photos from "Postcards From America" by Mark Power/Magnum Photos

“Everyone I know as a photographer has done a Blondie thing at this point, so I had waited a little bit,” said photographer, guitarist, and co-founder of Blondie, Chris Stein, about publishing his collection, Chris Stein/Negative: Me, Blondie and the Advent of Punk. “One of the key elements [today] is there’s no more underground, no more outside. Everyone is on the inside or the outside at this point, and everyone knows everything that’s going on immediately, so it’s really hard to have anything equivalent to what the underground was.” Above, Debbie Harry in sunglasses, late seventies.

When Sébastien Cuvelier started photographing the grand homes of wealthy Roma people in Romania in 2011, one thing became clear to him right away: In the communities he encountered, women ruled.  As a result, they became the focus of his book, Gypsy Queens, which Husson Editions published in 2013. Over a period of two years, Cuvelier visited Romania four times, photographing mostly in five Roma communities: Buzescu, Ciurea, Ivesti, Liesti, and Strehaia. “A lot of Roma people are frustrated by the treatment they receive from the general public, and I feel this was a way for these particular communities to say ‘I exist too, this is who I am,’ ” said Cuvelier. 
Above, Gabi and Ferdinand, both 15, on their wedding day. "I could get access to this special occasion as Gabi's mom remembered me from my previous visit, and I brought pictures of her younger daughter with me,” said Cuvelier. @sebastien.cuvelier

“I don’t know if it’s nostalgia, but people like to see the beginnings of things, and it does go beyond just the art, beyond the graffiti,” said sculptor Henry Chalfant. Together with photographer Martha Cooper, they worked to document the graffiti culture of NYC in the 70s and 80s, culminating in their classic book Subway Art, published in 1984, now released for the third time this month by Thames & Hudson. “It’s interesting to see how New York looked at the time,” said Chalfant. “I love photographs of that era just for that, they show a completely different, no-longer-happening time … now it’s a big market thing, the fashion and style is something you go to a store to buy, and back then you had creative people improvising and piecing together with what they had, and I think that’s really cool.” (Photo by Martha Cooper) @thamesandhudson
David Bowie, 1947-2016.

"I spent a month [in Memphis] walking on Elvis Presley Boulevard and trying to understand how this place became such an important pilgrimage destination," said photographer Clémentine Schneidermann. Portraits are the core of her series of Elvis festivals in Wales and Tennessee, I Called Her Lisa-Marie. "I was very moved by [fan] dedication," said Schneidermann. "The title comes from what Liz [a fan living in Newport, Wales] told me. Talking about her daughter she said ‘I call her Lisa-Marie, but she doesn’t know the meaning of it.’ I found that beautiful." Above, Little girl, Elvis Presley Boulevard, Memphis 2014. @clementineschneider

Steph Curry, the star of the Golden State Warriors and the best-shooting player in basketball, is the most exciting athlete of the year. And the most delightful thing about Steph Curry? His adorably strong-willed daughter, 3-year-old Riley, the star of every press conference she attends. Riley is how we know her father is mortal and not a jump-shooting basketball bot whose every circus shot goes swoosh, as if the basketball and the hoop were magnets, calling to one another over long distances. Riley Curry, and only Riley Curry, turns Steph Curry into a bystander, just another viewer of the exceedingly entertaining Riley Show. 
This joyful event brought to you by Slate's interactive calendar of #goodthings that took place in 2015, nominated by @willapaskin. @stephencurry30

"The streets are created by us, humans," said photographer Satoki Nagata. "We alone have the ability to create. We lead our lives in the environments that we create." Nagata has a Ph.D. in neuroscience and initially came to Chicago in 1992 for a job in that field. Although he enjoyed working in science, a decade later he felt the need to try something new and decided to study with the photographer Damaso Reyes. After four years, he quit his job to follow his passion independently; and street photography is where he "learned about photography as art, discovered [his] vision, learned about people’s lives, and thought about [himself]." His current series, Lights in Chicago, uses an off camera flash and low shutter speeds amidst the city's dark winter months to capture the complex connection between the individual and the photographer.

"I don’t know why I started chanting ‘Yeast infections!’ but it just came out. I have this cold, so it was just this obnoxious squeak, cheerleader-like. And I started doing high kicks, which I don’t normally do, in my skinny jeans," said @marynumair, who spontaneously broke up an anti Planned Parenthood protest down the street from her job, in Portland, Oregon on Oct. 25, 2015. Her sign, made out of cardboard from the dumpster, praised Planned Parenthood for treating her chronic yeast infections when she was in her early 20s and uninsured. "They do so much beyond abortions. I’m very much pro-choice, but if you want to take it beyond pro-choice and pro-life, there are … all these other things that are uncomfortable to talk about and [get treated if] you don’t want to wait two weeks to see your primary doctor or you don’t have health insurance," said Numair. 
This joyful event brought to you by Slate's interactive calendar of #goodthings that took place in 2015, with article by @portmantina. (Photo courtesy of Mary Numair) #PlannedParenthood

For the past 70 years, 95-year-old Walter Chandoha has made a career out of photographing cats for both editorial and commercial purposes. This year, @aperturenyc published a collection of Chandoha’s colorful cat photographs in the appropriately titled 'Walter Chandoha: The Cat Photographer'. Chandoha said he isn’t surprised by the huge presence cats have on the Internet since they are great subjects and technology has made it easier to photograph them.
“More importantly is how loveable cats are,” Chandoha said. “They make ideal companions.” @chandohacats

Monday night, space history was made by SpaceX. For the first time the first stage of a rocket came back from helping boost a payload to orbit and landed vertically back at the launch site. One of the major goals CEO Elon Musk had for SpaceX was to lower launch costs, making it easier to get into space, achieved this day. This also was the first Falcon 9 flight after one in June which failed catastrophically, with the entire payload (supplies for the space station) lost.

So, what’s next? The Falcon 9 first stage will now be thoroughly checked to see what damage it took and what it will take to clean it up and reuse it. Eventually, this will be a less expensive and faster process than building one from scratch. So in a sense, this test isn’t over: Once a booster is reused, then it will show that the next step in spaceflight has been truly achieved (much like, in a historical sense, the second flight of the Space Shuttle was just as important as the first). This joyful event brought to you by Slate's interactive calendar of #goodthings that took place in 2015, and @thebadastronomer.

Above, A remodeled version of the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on the launcher’s first mission since a June failure in Cape Canaveral, Florida, December 21, 2015. (Photo by Joe Skipper/Reuters)

Good news is hard to find. Amid the war, strife, and violence of this year, there were hundreds of things to cheer about. Slate has created an interactive Good Things calendar: a joyful event for each day of 2015, (nearly) 365 happy happenings that in aggregate add up to a powerful shot in the arm at the end of a year that sometimes felt dark indeed. Throughout the week we'll be featuring highlights from the year in our Instagram feed: including today's Good Things, the legalization of same sex marriage in the United States, Mexico, and Ireland. 
Above, Richard Dowlin and Cormac Gollogly kiss after becoming the the first gay couple to marry in Ireland, County Tipperary, Nov. 17, 2015. (Photo by Cathal McNaughton/Reuters) #goodthings

Holy sweet mother of Earth.

This incredible image was taken by the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter on Oct. 12, 2015, and the LRO has been mapping the Moon since it achieved orbit in 2009. On this occasion it was over the large crater Compton, which is just over the visible edge on the far side of the Moon, so it could peek over the horizon and see the Earth.

This is actually a combination of a few separate shots taken by LRO. The high-resolution narrow angle camera (or NAC) only takes grayscale images, while the lower-res wide angle camera (WAC) takes color. Both were used, processed, and combined to make this composite shot.

Read more from @thebadastronomer about this glorious Earthrise on Slate.
(Photo by NASA/Goddard/Arizona State University)

When gossip columnist Hedda Hopper called Elizabeth Taylor and asked about the rumors about her having an affair with Eddie Fisher, Liz did something completely shocking — she told the truth. Or, at least, her version of it. “I don’t go about breaking up marriages. You can’t break up a happy marriage. [Debbie Fischer]'s and Eddie’s never has been.” When Hedda asked Liz if she loved Eddie, Liz responded, “I like him very much, I’ve felt happier and more like a human being for the past two weeks than I have since Mike’s death.” Mike Todd and Liz were a power couple, until his death in 1958 when his private jet named Liz plummeted to the ground in New Mexico. “What do you suppose Mike would say to this?” Hedda demanded to know. Elizabeth responded, “Well, Mike is dead and I’m alive.” This was an echo of one of Liz’s most famous lines in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof—or, you could say, a preview of it, since most of Hedda Hopper’s readers hadn’t yet seen the film. But Liz would offer Hedda a kicker that was more explicitly sexual than anything the movie when she exclaimed, “What do you expect me to do? Sleep alone?” Read more from Karina Longworth's chronicle of how Elizabeth Taylor went from widow, to tramp, to oscar winner in 30 eventful months, on Slate. Above: Eddie Fisher and Elizabeth Taylor at the Academy Awards on April 17 1961. (Photo by Silver Screen Collection/Getty Images)

Robert E. Jackson has spent almost 20 years building a collection of nearly 12,000 vernacular photographs, mainly from the 1920s through the late ’60s, with a particular eye for the strange and uncanny. His expertly hand-picked photos have drawn attention largely for their ability to transcend nostalgia with what he describes as “pure photographic moments.” @slate is proud to present absurd and cringeworthy selections from @robert_e._jackson's archive of Christmas cards, read more from @jonfeinstein's article on our photo blog Behold.

Star Wars­­­ is a dazzling pastiche, as mashed-up and hyper-referential as any movie from Quentin Tarantino. It takes the blasters of Flash Gordon and puts them in the low-slung holsters of John Ford’s gunslingers. It takes Kurosawa’s samurai masters and sends them to Rick’s Café Américain from Casablanca. It takes the plot of The Hidden Fortress, pours it into Joseph Campbell’s mythological mold, and tops it all off with the climax from The Dam Busters. Writing of Star Wars’ place in the popular imagination in 1999, the critic J. Hoberman noted that the filmmaker Kevin Smith “remembers encountering classical mythology in school and assuming that the Greeks had ripped off Lucas.” Read more from 'Star Wars Is a Postmodern Masterpiece' by Forrest Wickham on Slate. (Photo illustration by @l_l_w)

Before dying from complications from AIDS in 1993, Tim Bailey asked his friends to throw his body over the White House gates as part of a political funeral. Bailey was a member of the ACT UP New York affinity group, ‘The Proud Marys’ and was photographed by Bill Bytsura in 1992. Bytsura went to his first ACT UP meeting in 1989, after his partner Randy died from AIDS-related complications. Because he was also a photographer, Bytsura joined ACT UP’s media committee and started to take portraits and document the stories of the activists. “It struck me that the media and public did not see them as I did, preferring to call them sinners, lawbreakers and disease carriers," said Bytsura. "I wanted the world to see these people as I did: Heroes fighting for their lives, putting their bodies on the line, searching for a cure.”

“Estimates on the numbers of homeless young people nationwide tend to vary widely—anywhere from 500,000 to 2.8 million—and often the terms are left undefined: What ages count as young? What does it mean to be homeless? How many of those young people are unaccompanied by parents? And how long are they homeless for? Estimates on how many of those young people are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer vary widely, too—from 20 to 40 percent. What is impossible to deny is that young people are kicked out—told to leave home—or pushed out—made so uncomfortable or unsafe they need to leave—with far greater frequency than most people realize and that this crisis is experienced disproportionately among LGBTQ youth.” Above, Mahfoud, once homeless, is now a fashion designer who loves to play with gender; photographed by Alex Fradkin on behalf of the Reciprocity Foundation, a homeless youth organization based in New York City. 
Read more from Stephen Vider and David S Byers feature on the history of LGBTQ homelessness, and what queer activists today can do to help, on Slate.

Using camera traps along with flashes, Jonny Armstrong captures unusually unguarded nature photos. As a working ecologist, he also uses camera traps for scientific purposes. Yet, said Armstrong, “my research photos ... fail to capture the beauty of nature. My personal photos strive to do what my science cannot—emotionally engage audiences.” Above, A red fox searches for food at water’s edge. @jonnybarmstrong

"The narrative impulse is one entwined with anorexia itself. Being sick means constructing an alternate reality, strapping it in place with sturdy mantras, surrendering to the beguiling logic of an old fairy tale: There once was a girl who ate very little. There once lived a witch in a deep, dark wood. Anorexics are convinced that they are hideous, bad, and unlovable. At the same time, they are constantly soliloquizing about their sacrifice, their nobility, their ethereal powers." Read more from Katy Waldman's remarkable memoir breaking through the false narratives around anorexia on Slate. (Illustration by @aidanalexiskoch)

Migrants protest behind a fence against restrictions limiting passage at the Greek-Macedonian border, near Gevgelija, Macedonia, on Dec. 1, 2015. Since last week, Macedonia has restricted passage to northern Europe to only Syrians, Iraqis, and Afghans who are considered war refugees. All other nationalities are deemed economic migrants and told to turn back. Macedonia on Nov. 29 finished building a fence on its frontier with Greece, becoming the latest country in Europe to build a border barrier aimed at checking the flow of migrants. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Armend Nimani/AFP/Getty Images)

People hike on the Perito Moreno Glacier in Los Glaciares National Park, part of the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, on Nov. 30, 2015, in Santa Cruz province, Argentina. The Southern Patagonian Ice Field is the third largest ice field in the world. The majority of the almost 50 large glaciers in Los Glaciares National Park have been retreating during the past 50 years due to warming temperatures, according to the European Space Agency. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Harold Burdekin & John Morrison photographed the streets of the city of London in the dark for his book London Night, published in 1934. In a time before stricter air pollution controls, the pair chose foggy nights to make their images, giving the light in the photos a sense of weighty presence.

Above: Regent Street, Piccadilly. (Photo courtesy of Bishopsgate Institute)

"The only reason you have not been shot is because nobody has yet decided to shoot you. Our patchwork of mostly loose state gun laws, combined with weak federal standards, ensures that anybody who wants a firearm can obtain one. 
But, let us assume that private gun ownership may be an aspect of constitutional liberty. In that case, we must balance “respect for the liberty of the individual” against “the demands on the organized society.” On one side of this equation, we have America today, which is what gun advocates have wanted all along: A freewheeling, disjointed legal framework which ultimately allows virtually anyone to access a gun. It has produced a greater number of mass shootings than this country has ever seen. 
On the other side, we have the possibility of fewer mass shootings and fewer gun deaths. We could make that possibility a reality, but we could only do so by limiting access to firearms. Gun advocates insist that the trade-off isn’t worth it—that endless mass shootings may simply be the price we pay for liberty. Now the country must decide: Is this liberty worth its cost in human lives?" —Mark Joseph Stern, "If Gun Massacres Are the Price of Liberty, We Need to Reconsider What Liberty Means"

A still image from video footage shows people lining up as first responders respond to the shooting at the California Department of Developmental Services Inland Regional Center, which serves people with developmental disabilities, in San Bernardino, California, Dec. 2, 2015. (by NBCLA.COM via Reuters)

What became of assets that were seized by Fidel Castro when he came to power and nationalized the Cuban economy? @sethstevenson explains the economic history of lost property claims held by Americans today, assessed at a total value of $1.9 billion in the 1950s—of claim-holders unsure of what their old pieces of paper might be worth now, of sharks who want to corner the market on these risky but potentially very valuable assets, and of America's persistent romanticism when it comes to Cuba.

Above, street life near the Capital building, Havana, Dec. 22, 2014. (Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown/@magnumphotos)

Kiev, Ukraine–based Anna Marinenko was inspired by a skein of gigantically thick wool last year. Made under the name Ohhio, she creates creates chunky-knit blankets using her bare hands to knit in place of knitting needles. Made from fine 100 percent Merino wool, her creations are warm in winter and lightweight enough to keep around in summer. Her work is available on Etsy, where she offers blankets in a range of sizes colors and takes custom orders (and also sells a range of chunky-knit pet beds). @anna.mo.ohhio

This week, the video of Chicago Police Officer Jason Van Dyke shooting Laquan McDonald was released, a year since McDonald's death Oct. 20, 2014. Chicago went from being all but silent on McDonald’s death to condemning the officer who caused it, charging Van Dyke with first-degree murder; in a move that was widely interpreted as the result of political calculation. #blacklivesmatter protesters have rallied around the country, seen here in New York City. #4thPrecinctShutDown (Photos by @aymanndotcom)

Who is Dominican? What do Dominicans look like? Colombian-American photographer Antonio Pulgarin @antonio_pulgarin has been making visits to his Dominican stepfather’s city, Bani, since he was a kid. This summer, when the government started deportations, he knew he had to return there to witness the deportation crisis, and to create a more positive narrative about the country’s diversity. The result is his series, “Los Banilejos,” a term used to describe people who live in Bani—a term, Pulgarin notes, not limited to a specific skin color or background.
“This project is not meant to be a criticism of the people but more of a celebration of these individuals and the culture. What it does criticize is a political system that needs to change. We all need to realize that no one Dominican person should be considered less or more than the other,” Pulgarin said.

Above, Siblings at Night.

Sunday night’s sunset in New York City was a showstopper. What? You missed it?! Well, you’re in luck: Three enterprising Pennsylvania meteorologists want to make sure nothing like that ever happens again. Enter: #SunsetWx. The project is still very much a work in progress—it just launched last week—but it appears to be the first systematic attempt at a rigorous, meteorologically based daily sunset quality forecast coast to coast. Basically, the model blends high-resolution forecasts of humidity, pressure changes, and clouds at various levels of the atmosphere, weighting wispy upper-level clouds the strongest and penalizing for thick, low-level clouds or average clear sky evenings. “We take it for granted sometimes that we have nature and weather around us,” said co-founder Jacob DeFlitch. “This, hopefully, will help people to go out and see for themselves.” (Photo by @l_l_w)

Painting outside the lines over the years has created a spectacular display of shapes and colors and textures at the Portland Child Art Studio, captured vividly by photographer @stevenhirsch. Though he once found primary inspiration in people: outcasts, prostitutes, alien abductees, and criminals; his current passion for abstract images started with an epiphany five years ago staring at the psychedelic and polluted water surface of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. Since then, he’s found it in other unlikely places—rust, grease, paint, corrosion, stains, crushed computer parts, even bird droppings, all part of his series, "Splat," on display at Miami Project from Dec. 1–6 through @madelynjordonfa.

People cheer Malian soldiers in front of the Radisson hotel in Bamako, Mali, on Nov. 20, 2015. Jihadi gunmen attacked the hotel earlier in the day, taking more than 100 people hostage and killing as many as 27 people. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Joe Penney/Reuters)

This is by far the coolest pileus cloud with iridescence you’ll see all day. 
Allow @thebadastronomer to explain. Pileus clouds are thin, cap-shaped, form above rapidly rising columns of air, and have tiny water droplets in them. And iridescence is a weird phenomenon. You need lots of tiny raindrops (or ice crystals) all the same size over a large portion of the cloud. In a rainbow, the lights goes into the droplets and gets bent (twice) to create colors. In iridescence, though, the light actually bends (diffracts) around the droplets. Different colors bend by different amounts, splitting the colors apart. The size of the raindrop needs to be roughly the same size as the wavelength of light, so when I say “tiny” I mean it: The drops must be less around a micron in size! A human hair, by the way, is about 100 microns in width, so these really are teensy drops. 
Beckie Bone Dunning snapped this shot in Jamaica on Oct. 29, 2015, as storm clouds were approaching, almost covering the Sun, perfect conditions for this phenomenon. Voilà! #🌈

"Remember the toddler who threw a tantrum in front of the President? That was my kid."
Visit Slate to read Laura Moser's memoir on the time she went to Passover Seder dinner at the White House and how a photo by @petesouza of her daughter having a fit at the feet of President Obama went viral.

Pulp science fiction might have helped to create the science culture in which women feel out of place and sometimes even unwelcome. In the random sample of 560 pulp science fiction stories studied by Elizabeth Garbee, she found only three female characters whom we would call scientists. Even today, when an author writes a male scientist, he’s just writing a scientist: But when he writes a female scientist, he’s making a statement. If we as a country value a STEM workforce that is strong and competitive through its diversity, if we’re serious about creating a culture of equal opportunity in the sciences, then we still have work to do. (Image courtesy Love Romances)

Jannat, 12, who was wounded in the ISIS led suicide bombing in Lebanon that claimed the lives of 43 people, gives the peace sign while being treated for her injuries, Nov. 13, 2015. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Anwar Amro/AFP/Getty Images)
Candlelight vigil at the French Consulate in Los Angeles. 🇫🇷#Peace4ParisVigil #JeSuisParis (Photo by @aymanndotcom)
Even on this darkest day, the city of lights will shine on. #paris #parisjetaime #jesuisparis
The Starbucks red cup controversy, fixed by @thebadastronomer and @l_l_w. #itsjustacup

Last weekend — on Nov. 7, 2015 — a mysterious bright fan of light swept across the sky on the US west coast. It was seen by perhaps hundreds of thousands of people, many of whom, understandably, were pretty flipped out by it.

It was quickly determined to be an unarmed Trident II missile test launched by a submarine in the Pacific. The missile is a three-stage affair; when one stage burns out a small explosion is triggered which separates it from the rest of the missile, the next stage ignites, and off it goes again.

Porter Tinsley, who was taking photographs on the shore of the southern California Salton Sea at the time, was able to capture fantastic shots of the launch. Above, a long exposure photo of gas being released by the missile expanded into a halo, lighting up the night sky. Visit Bad Astronomy on Slate to see the full animation of Tinsley's photos of the missile launch. @thebadastronomer

Kerid Crater Lake is unique among crater lakes in that its caldera likely didn't form from an explosion as most do. Located in southern Iceland along the so-called Golden Circle, the Kerid volcano is thought to have formed when the magma in the center simply depleted itself and the empty chamber beneath caved in. Regardless of the geological minutia that led to the lake's creation, its bright rainbow of colors look unearthly. (Photo by Progresschrome/Creative Commons) @atlasobscura #keridcraterlake

Alice Wheeler moved to Seattle when she was 19, taking her camera everywhere and documenting the creative and collaborative spirit of the grunge era; a collection of this work, Outcasts & Innocents, was published this year by Minor Matters. Above, Kathleen Hanna at her apartment, Olympia, Washington, November 1992. (Photo courtesy Minor Matters Books and Greg Kucera Gallery) @minormattersbooks @gregkuceragallery @mskathleenhanna #alicewheeler #kathleenhanna

Participants balance on slacklines set up between rocks in the Cantagalo favela community during the Highgirls Brasil festival on November 2, 2015 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The event was femaled-focused and allowed men to participate in female attire. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Troy Parkinson riding Excess Knowledge from Gai Waterhouse Racing during a trackwork session at Altona Beach on Nov. 1, 2015 in Melbourne, Australia. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Vince Caligiuri/Getty Images)

The Kakslauttanen Arctic Resort was started back in 1973 when its founder, Jussi, was traveling down the lonely roads just south of Finland's northernmost fishing village. As the story goes, his car broke down, and he was forced to make camp near the isolated roadside woods. Instead of just thinking of this excursion as a minor inconvenience, he fell in love with the spot and set up a permanent roadside stop-in that eventually grew up to be the current luxury resort; most notably including a field of glass igloos that grant guests a completely unobstructed view of the Northern Lights. (Photo courtesy Greenland Travel/Flickr Creative Commons)

Anyone who has ever seen Michelangelo’s David at the the Uffizi Museum in Florence, Italy, has surely fantasized about having that 16-foot, 5-ton solid marble ode to manhood come to life. Out of your art historical dreams and into your home, the Table Museum has created a series of action figures including Michelangelo’s David, Rodin’s The Thinker, and the Venus de Milo. Manufactured by Japanese company FREEing, the roughly 6-inch-tall PVC figurines are equipped with articulated joints and poseable limbs, and can be ordered online from the Good Smile Company. @goodsmilecompany #davidmichelangelo

At 65, Steve McCurry is one of the world’s best-traveled photojournalists, but in 1978 he was still relatively new to globe-trotting. He had already lived in Europe for a year and been to parts of Latin America and Africa when he decided to travel to India. It was his first time in Asia, and, when he arrived, he was stunned. “I was so taken with the excitement, the array of different religions, the disparity between rich and poor, people living in a very ancient way and other people living in quite a modern way,” he said.

Highlights from three decades of McCurry’s travels are featured in an exhibit at New York’s Rubin Museum of Art in partnership with the International Center of Photography, “Steve McCurry: India,” which runs from Nov. 18 to April 5.
Above, a dust storm in Rajasthan.
@stevemccurryofficial @rubinmuseum @icp

A vast cloud of gas surrounding two huge clusters of stars stares at you, glaring, knowing you should be in the moment and not distracting yourself with Instagram. Or is that your conscience speaking? This is actually a star-forming cloud called NGC 2467, as seen by the MPG/ESO telescope in Chile. Each eye is actually a cluster of stars, blowing huge holes in the gas cloud, forming what looks like two colorful eyes burning a hole into your very soul. Important to note: This object is in the constellation of Puppis, the stern of a cosmic ship. So this really is a stern glare! See more from @thebadastronomer's cosmic Halloween gallery on Slate. (Photo courtesy of ESO)

Los Angeles–based artist Christine McConnell turned her parents’ home into a creepy homage to the 2006 movie Monster House. “I'm such a huge fan of Halloween and binge-watch every creepy movie imaginable during this time of year,” McConnell said. She made the eyeball and teeth decorations using inexpensive foam core insulation boards and latex paint from Lowe’s. “I think more people should figure out things they can do on their own. That’s how you find out what you're really good at.” @christinehmcconnell

Do couples need prenups for their shared streaming passwords? Sharing passwords to video-on-demand sites is a telling step in contemporary coupling—a contemporary version of leaving an extra toothbrush in your partner’s bathroom. However small, it’s a gesture of trust and generosity; it suggests that you’ll spend more time together than apart. On streaming platforms that keep track of users’ viewing histories, it becomes a tiny window into your partner’s desires and habits. And, if and when the relationship withers, it’s another formal link to sever. Visit Slate.com to read more from Ex Flix by Christina Cauterucci @portmantina. (Illustration by Natalie Matthews-Ramo)

Two baby Sumatran orangutans play at the wildlife department in Kuala Lumpur, Malayasia, on Oct. 19, 2015. The Malaysian wildlife department seized the pair, found in duffel bags, in July from traffickers who were attempting to sell them to buyers in Malaysia. According to local media, the orangutans will be returned to Medan, Indonesia. The illegal wildlife trade is estimated to be $8 billion a year worldwide, according to TRAFFIC, a wildlife trade monitoring network. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Olivia Harris/Reuters)

Migrants are escorted by police to a holding camp on Oct. 22, 2015, in Dobova, Slovenia. Thousands of migrants marched across the border from Croatia into Slovenia as authorities intensify their efforts to attempt to cope with a human tide unseen in Europe since World War II. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images)

Montreal’s Metro was inaugurated nearly 50 years ago by then–Mayor Jean Drapeau, who held a competition challenging architects to individually design its 26 (now 68) stations. A testament to modernist architecture, the underground stations are embellished with more than 100 works of public art that include murals, sculpture, and stained glass.

Chris Forsyth has celebrated the beauty of the Montreal Metro with a series of graphic, well-composed photos posted on Instagram (@chrismforsyth), as seen above at Sherbrooke station; and a community of Metro-loving photographers have added their own photos under the hashtag #mtlmetroproject as well.

"[I had conversations with home schooled kids] almost as if they were adults," said photographer Rachel Papo. Her series of portraits, "Homeschooled," was taken in the Woodstock area since she relocated there in 2010, and discovered that home schooling was fairly common in the area. "This whole time [I’m working on the series] I’m trying to form my own opinion: Am I against it, or am I for it? Would I do it? I’m really stuck in the middle. I like these kids because their knowledge isn’t just academic; they have life experience I don’t know if every kid gets." Above, Roan With Kilda and April, 2011. @rachelpapo

In 1972, the Johnson Publishing Company, publisher of Ebony and Jet magazines, moved into their Chicago headquarters. Designed by John W. Moutoussamy, it was the first major downtown building in Chicago designed and owned by black people in more than two centuries.

Barbara Karant, an adjunct professor at Columbia College Chicago, has long been interested in the building, and when Johnson Publishing sold the building to Columbia in 2010, she sought permission to photograph it. Since 2013, she has been working on the series "820 Ebony/Jet." The building is only heated enough in the winter to prevent pipes from bursting, and in the summer there is no air conditioning. As a result, Karant works from around November until May often in freezing conditions. Locked in the building solo and conducting 6 hour sessions each shooting day, she explored the 11 floors and 110,000 square feet of space at times with only the light of her iPhone. "Most corporations will renovate and change and update their environment," said Karant. "What [Johnson Publishing] did was maintain and clean and bring back to pristine the environment but it never changed from 1972 until they moved out in 2012. It’s really a modernist time capsule; not a lot of these still exist. It’s very unique." #ebonyjet

Last Friday’s 3-0 ruling in favor of the Google Books digitization project is a big deal not just for search engine giants, copyright lawyers, authors, and publishers, but also for ordinary people. Only a generation ago, doing scholarly research in the way that Google Books now makes possible was a game only academics could play, and at that, had to master arcane skills (managing card catalogs, for example) and arrange access to the holdings of research libraries just to make sure they didn't miss any relevant materials. Even then, scholars with full access to troves of material in university libraries or museum collections couldn’t do the kind of digital analysis (even if sometimes flawed) that Google’s full-text searches now extend potentially to everyone. Above, the Rose Main Reading Room of New York Public Library, one of more than 40 partner libraries to the Google Books project. (Photo by Marcio Jose Bastos Silva/Shutterstock)
A woman pushes a stroller around Dream Lake amid fall foliage in Amherst, New Hampshire, on Oct. 13, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Brian Snyder/Reuters)

People rest in hammocks as they experience the Chronarium Sleep Lab, a public sleep laboratory presented in audiovisual environment by British group Loop.pH during the Festival of Tech in Singapore on Oct. 12, 2015. The installation, inspired by chronobiology or biological rhythms, makes use of sound and artificial lighting to help the brain develop a deep relaxation and rest over a 15 minute period. According to the group, the laboratory explores the role of public space and use of technology in helping people cope with insufficient sleep in modern city life. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Edgar Su/Reuters)

Built in Tokyo in 1972, the Nakagin Capsule Tower is a concrete structure upon which 140 removable “capsules,” roughly 100 square feet in size, have been attached to one another to be used as living or work spaces. The photographer Noritaka Minami first visited the tower in 2010 and was “immediately … captivated by the building’s history and the experience of being inside a capsule that was first plugged into the concrete core in 1972.” Kehrer Verlag collected these images in the book 1972, which recently won book of the year award from Deutsches Architekturmuseum in Frankfurt. @kehrerverlag #nakagincapsuletower

"I was a painter before I was a photographer so I think about the portrait historically," said Aline Smithson. "As a photographer I feel like I am reflecting back onto my subject … the experience is a reflection of self, and I hope through the experience the subject reveals something they don't normally share with the camera." Smithson’s first book that comprises two decades of her portraiture, Self & Others: Portrait as Autobiography, was published this month by the Magenta Foundation. Above, Cleo With a Mirror. @alinesmithson

When Jesse Burke’s oldest daughter, Clover, was nearly 5, he took her on a road trip from their home in Rhode Island up the coast to Canada. His plan was to photograph landscapes, but inevitably, he started taking photos of Clover as well. Halfway through their journey, he realized that those photos were the most interesting ones. Wild & Precious, which will be published by Daylight Books on Oct. 15, collects photos from more than two dozen trips the pair took together over the next five years. @jesse_burke

Children pose for their parents on a rock in front of the Bolshoy (Big) Almaty lake at 2,600 meters (8,530 feet) above sea level at a sunny autumn day in a mountains outside Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Oct. 4, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Shamil Zhumatov/Reuters)

"A lot of people have dreams; then they get a job and have a family. And then they get to be 40 or 50 and suddenly realize all their dreams just fell by the wayside. I didn’t want that to happen to me." Ethan Schlussler returned to his childhood home in Sandpoint, Idaho, to build the treehouse bedroom he always fantasized about having in his backyard. This treehouse, complete with a pedal-powered bicycle elevator, is one of the many handmade structures featured in the recently published book, Cabin Porn, by Zach Klein with Steven Leckart. (Photo by Noah Kalina) @cabinporn @noahkalina

Picture taken from Quito, Ecuador, of the Cotopaxi volcano spewing ash on Oct. 8, 2015. The volcanic activity, which began Aug. 14 after 138 years of silence, continued with "steam emissions and a moderate load of ash," the country's security ministry said. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Rodrigo Buendia/AFP/Getty Images)

In the late 1970s, Charles Traub would bring along his Rolleiflex SL66 camera to photograph passers-by during his lunch break, while working at Columbia College in Chicago, and later at  Light Gallery in NYC. Nearly 40 years later, Damiani has published 100 of Traub’s images in a collection appropriately titled 'Lunchtime'. “You dress for a reason, or you don’t dress for a reason but there’s a sense of yourself in how you present yourself to the world, and I think if someone notices that or compliments it or recognizes it, people are quite pleased about that,” Traub said. “They feel individualized and they feel accepted.”

“[This] whole series is about growing up, that moment where you’re at the threshold of adulthood. You’re attached to a kind of innocence, but that’s disappearing,” said Doug DuBois of 'My Last Day at Seventeen', a photographic coming-of-age narrative that takes place in Cobh, a small seaside town in County Cork, Ireland. Above, Jordan up the Pole, Russell Heights, Cobh, Ireland, 2010.

A baby manatee plays against the glass in one of its very first public appearances on Oct. 1, 2015, in Genoa, Italy. The manatee is the only one in Italy, and only 10 zoos in Europe have these herbivorous marine mammals. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Awakening/Getty Images)
A surfer catches a wave on his board as a supermoon rises off Manly Beach in Sydney on Sept. 28, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by David Gray/Reuters)

The Pearly Queen of Smithfield Market arrives at the Church of St. Mary-le-Bow to attend the service for the 17th Pearly Kings and Queens Harvest Festival on Sept. 27, 2015, in London. The tradition of the Pearly Kings and Queens dates back to 1875, and today 30 London families keep the tradition alive, raising money for charities across the city and attending London’s events in their colorful handmade costumes. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Mary Turner/Getty Images)

Syrian refugees are given life blankets upon arriving on the Greek island of Lesbos after crossing the Aegean Sea from Turkey on Sept. 28, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Aris Messinis/AFP/Getty Images)

“What I was able to do is never going to happen again,” said photographer Janet Macoska. “We’re probably dinosaurs, and you’re seeing the last of the species. When rock ’n’ roll was in its infancy, you pretty much were at the same level as the band; you were the photographer, and they were the musicians, and everyone wanted to make it. … Everyone was cool about hanging out and making photos and making music and no one was a threat to anyone else.” In August, her book 'All Access Cleveland: The Rock and Roll Photography of Janet Macoska', was published, including 340 images (edited down from more than 1 million) and stories from her 40-year career shooting music, mostly in the Cleveland area. Above, Freddie Mercury, 1975.

Phytoplankton blooms are huge bursts of growth (usually of cyanobacteria) occurring in warmer water where nutrients and sunlight become abundant. Blooms can extend hundreds of kilometers across and are potentially dangerous; certain phytoplanktons are toxic, and many blooms can rob water of oxygen. The image above shows (a small part of) a phytoplankton bloom in the Baltic Sea, just north of Poland, taken by Landsat 8, a @NASA/@USGS earth observation satellite, on Aug. 11, 2015. Visit Slate for more from @thebadastronomer on the remarkable coincidence of this image with another satellite photo taken by @europeanspaceagency days before. (Photo by Norman Kuring, NASA’s Ocean Color Web)

Chief Solomon Osagie Alonge was a one-of-a-kind photographer. For 50 years, he was the official photographer of the royal court of Benin, Nigeria, and also was the most sought after portrait photographer in the city amongst the elite of Nigerian society. His photographs currently on display at the @nmafa through Jan. 10, present an unprecedented social history of the city as Nigeria achieved independence.

Left: Man and wife seated. Right: Portrait taken at Ideal Photo Studio, Benin City, Nigeria.

In 2008, Toni Greaves began documenting the life of nuns at Dominican Monastery of Our Lady of the Rosaryin Summit, New Jersey. Roughly three weeks earlier, Sister Lauren, then 21, had entered the monastery after hearing God propose to her via a song on YouTube, leaving behind a boyfriend whom she’d planned on marrying. "She has an amazing wonderful energy and she had only been there for a few weeks; from the beginning the story was clearly about her," said Greaves. Over the next seven years, she captured Sister Lauren’s path from layperson to nun. The photos appear in Radical Love, published this week by Chronicle Books, which also was one of the books offered to Pope Francis in his room during his stay in New York City.

Above: Nov. 1, 2008. Sister Lauren, 22, receives her white veil (fitted by Sister Mary Martin, Prioress) in her Clothing Ceremony, which is similar to an engagement to God. Within this ceremony she receives the Dominican habit, and takes a new holy name of her choosing: Sister Maria Teresa of the Sacred Heart. @tonigreaves @chroniclebooks

On Sept. 27 and 28, the Moon will enter Earth’s shadow, creating a total lunar eclipse, remarkable also because it will occur during a supermoon. In the U.S., the event begins Sunday night, starting at around 8PM EDT; for most of the country the Moon will be low to the eastern horizon. At that time you’ll start to see a dark “bite” taken out of the Moon on the part of it nearest the horizon (the lower left, again for Americans). The eclipse will reach peak shade around 10:47 EDT. 
Above, an astronomer stargazes ahead of the supermoon eclipse on the evening of Sept. 27, 2015 in Brighton, England. (Photo by Jordan Mansfield/Getty Images)

Guillaume Rolland of France stands on a line during the Highline Extreme event in Moleson, Switzerland, on Sept. 25, 2015. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Denis Balibouse/Reuters)

People gather at the historic Chand Baori stepwell in Abhaneri, India, on Sept. 24, 2015. For a few hours on one day each year, local residents are permitted to descend into the 100-foot-deep, 1,200-year-old stepwell, as Hindu devotees in the area mark a local festival, at the same time as Hindus worldwide observe Ganesh Chaturthi festivities. Chand Baori is one of the oldest and largest stepwells in the world, with some 3,500 steps laid out in a geometric design down to the water at its base. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Alex Ogle/AFP/Getty Images)

Pope Francis’ visit to New York City enters its final day, with a robust schedule taking the leader of the Catholic Church from Lower Manhattan to East Harlem, culminating in Mass at Madison Square Garden before he heads to Philadelphia. The day began at the United Nations headquarters, to address the General Assembly. Above, U.N. personnel take pictures as Pope Francis arrives to greet UN staff members at United Nations headquarters, Sept. 25, 2015. Visit Slate for more coverage of Pope Francis’ U.S. visit. (Photo by Kevin Hagen/Pool via Reuters)

The great monkey-selfie imbroglio of 2014 is back in the news this week thanks to a federal lawsuit by—who else?—PETA, which claims that the crested black macaque who snapped the photo up above should own its copyright. As of now, the government only issues copyrights to human authors, a legal tradition that is unlikely to change. “The fact is, copyright’s not there to reward people for their labor—it's to incentivize people to create new books or poems," said Chris Sprigman, a law professor at New York University in an interview with @jhweissmann. “Did this guy need an incentive to produce monkey selfies? No. He needed an incentive to go to Indonesia to take photographs. And by accident, he ended up with monkey selfies. The monkeys didn’t need incentives, either. They just did it for the pure pleasure of hearing the shutter click.” Visit Slate.com for more from 'If a Monkey Takes a Selfie, Who Owns the Copyright?' (Photo by Monkey via Wikimedia Commons)

During the 1980s, many photographers responded to the escalating risk of nuclear confrontation by taking an active stance against proliferation. Some artists, like Sandy Skoglund, responded to the atomic age with dark humor that addressed the dangers of nuclear energy and weaponry. 'Radioactive Cats' depicts dozens of sculpted plaster cats covered with Day-Glo paint, an absurd yet iconic statement amidst the atomic age and the Cold War. (Photo courtesy Smith College Museum of Art, Northampton, Massachusetts, ©1980 Sandy Skoglund)

"I think what draws people to faith is that un-namable, unknown quality that all people understand even if they can’t articulate it," said photographer Melodie McDaniel. "It’s a shared, loving energy that brings people together, and allows them to be lifted up or transform in some way—it allows them to know or feel the Divine. I discovered that once there’s this shared experience, be it faith-based or inviting someone into a particular sub-culture, there’s really no judgment. Once people trust or journey to this space, this safe haven, all lines of race, creed or color are lifted and erased." Above, Sunday Best 4, 1995, now on view at Spot Gallery in Los Angeles, as part of the exhibition "American Spectator" through Nov. 9.

“As you start to go gray there’s a lot of pressure not to be gray,” said photographer Pam Connolly. “People say they can’t stand looking at themselves [in the mirror when waiting for the color to take hold]. It’s very vulnerable, and I was struck by that. [I've been there, just trying to] grin and bear it, and I said, ‘OK, just look—really look—at the wrinkles.’ And when I looked, it wasn’t really that bad and I thought, ‘Why are we so afraid to look at ourselves? Why are we afraid to look the age we are?’ ”

Above, Natalie, from ‘Salon Studies’ by Pam Connolly.

A white lion is seen at the Parque Loro zoo in Puebla, Mexico, on Sept. 12, 2015. This is one of three white lions born in captivity, two of which have already been donated or delivered under exchange agreements with other zoos in Mexico. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Jose Castanares/AFP/Getty Images)

A tourist on a boat takes a photograph of the waterfront on the banks of the River Ganges at Varanasi on Sept. 18, 2015. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Alex Ogle/AFP/Getty Images)

Workers who commute by bike to the Alphabeta building in London can enter at street level and ride to the basement via a dedicated ramp designed by Studio RHE. The design includes underground storage for more than 200 bikes as well as adjacent changing rooms and lockers, as part of a building redesign meant to attract a mix of media, tech, and finance companies from the surrounding area. (Photo by @huftonandcrow) #theeyeslate

Ruth Bader Ginsburg is going to take a break from serving as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court to guest host a radio program on Chicago’s WFMT, Monday, September 21.
Ginsburg, a well-known opera aficionado, will share some of her favorite music and discuss Opera and the Law with regular host Lisa Flynn, followed by a performance by singers from The Patrick G. and Shirley W. Ryan Opera Center of @lyricopera of legal-themed operatic excerpts selected by RBG herself. (Photo illustration by @l_l_w)

Traer Scott’s book Shelter Dogs, a heartbreaking collection of portraits of dogs living in shelters, was a runaway success when it came out in 2006. In addition to the portraits, at the end of the book Scott wrote about what happened to the dogs, specifying if they’d been rescued or euthanized. Now, nearly a decade later, Scott has completed a more in-depth work: Finding Home: Shelter Dogs & Their Stories. "While a dog is in a shelter the attention it gets from staff or volunteers will literally make the difference whether they live or die," said Scott. "If it’s getting out of walks, getting training … getting a break from constant confinement … the dog stands a good chance of making it out of that situation, whereas a dog that is locked in a kennel 24 hours a day, seven days a week—that happens so much—is just going to lose its mind." @papress @traer_scott

Lithuanian photographer Agne Gintalaite has documented a series of some 200 Lithuanian garage doors painted and weathered by the elements and time on the outskirts of Vilnius that look like Mark Rothko paintings left out in the rain, each its own stunning work of abstract art. The photographer said that she had always been intrigued by “a peculiar phenomenon of late socialism,” with an impulse to capture the ephemeral aesthetic as well as a nod to the owners of the garages, who she described as most likely elderly and of modest means, relics of a bygone era standing their ground “in an urban landscape on which big businesses increasingly make claim.”

Portrait photography has long been a collaborative process in Africa, and subjects in photographs are often able to express themselves just as fully as the one clicking the shutter button. “In a lot of the photos you see a very direct gaze. You have this sense that the person being photographed is conscious of what’s happening and also has a very commanding posture and is taking charge of their own image,” said Yaëlle Biro, co-curator of “In and Out of the Studio: Photographic Portraits from West Africa,” on view at @metmuseum through Jan. 3. Above, Reclining Woman, 1950s–1960s by Seydou Keïta.

Ansel Adams was already world-famous for his groundbreaking black-and-white photographs of the American West when he was invited by his friend Ralph Merritt to document the Manzanar War Relocation Center, a Japanese internment camp, where Merritt was director. It was a risky career move for a man so thoroughly established as a landscape photographer, but Adams was compelled to witness life there and make a record of it. "He felt this was an injustice and he actually ended up conducting interviews with people in the camp, asking people about their experiences, how they felt prior to incarceration, whether they’d experienced racial prejudice before the war. He tried to capture not only what was happening in the camps visually but he wanted to know who these people were. He wanted to emphasize their loyalty as American citizens," said Linde B. Lehtinen, assistant curator at @skirball_la, where "Manzanar: The Wartime Photographs of Ansel Adams" will be shown from Oct. 8 - Feb. 21. 
Above, School Children, 1943. (Private collection; courtesy of Photographic Traveling Exhibitions)
Tourists visit the famous Pontocho Alley on Sept. 7, 2015, in Kyoto, Japan. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Chris McGrath/Getty Images)

Fabien Napias of the French Recortadores company Passion Saltador leaps over a charging bull at the end of the Liga de Corte Puro finals at the Plaza de Toros on Sept. 6, 2015, in Valladolid, Spain. The art consists of leaping, diving, and somersaulting over charging bulls. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Denis Doyle/Getty Images)
