A competitor balances on the “gostra,” a pole covered in grease, during the celebrations for the religious feast of St. Julian, patron of the town of St. Julian’s, outside Valletta, Malta, on Aug. 30, 2015. In the traditional gostra, a game stretching back to the Middle Ages, young men, women, and children have to make their way to the top of a pole and try to uproot one of the flags to win prizes. From May to September in Malta, there is hardly any weekend when a town or a village is not celebrating the feast of its patron saint or other saints revered in different churches. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Darrin Zammit Lupi/Reuters)

Migrants walk through a field to cross the border from Greece to Macedonia near the Greek village of Idomeni on Aug. 29, 2015. The EU is grappling with an unprecedented influx of people fleeing war, repression, and poverty in what the bloc has described as its worst refugee crisis in 50 years. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Aris Messinis/AFP/Getty Images)

Scientists on social media are redefining “cute.” Prompted by two researchers at Virginia Tech, Anne Hillborn and Marcella Kelly, scientists have been posting photos of their most adorable research organisms to Twitter with the hashtag #CuteOff. Whether or not these critters qualify may be in the eye—or the research study—of the beholder. The thoughts and opinions expressed above about the cuteness of fuzzy baby emperor penguins by Assistant Art Director @l_l_w do not necessarily reflect the views of Slate Magazine. (Photo by Wolfgang Kaehler/LightRocket via Getty Images)

Cackalacky! Wicked! Dingnation! Grabowski! Welcome to the United Slang of America. We stand by our picks. But if you’ve lived in Kansas for 75 years and have never heard anyone say “shucky darn,” or you grew up in Mississippi and have no idea what “nabs” are, by all means be heard. Enjoy the map and fear the glawackus. (Illustration by @l_l_w)

“The energetic atmosphere, the optimism, the feeling that one can become whatever or whomever they want to be, the careers of these self-made models, photographers and actors … of course that’s attractive!” said Zippora Elders, who is curating the exhibition “Swinging Sixties London: Photography in the Capital of Cool,” at the Amsterdam photography museum @foam_amsterdam. “I don’t think future generations could ever feel that way anymore, especially after the 1970s crises and the emerging of punk … everyone can remember what it was to be young, ambitious, and perhaps naive; in the end, there are always limits.” Above, Jane Birkin, 1965. (Photo by Eric Swayne)

Ray Yoshida, a Hawaii-born artist who taught at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago for more than 40 years, was a painter and collagist, who also collected images from comics, grouping scraps together in loose typologies: hands; explosions; kisses; the sea. The Smithsonian's Archives of American Art recently digitized a scrapbook of comic book art he assembled in (they believe) the late 1960s. (Courtesy of the Archives of American Art) @smithsonian #rayyoshida

Giant panda cubs rest inside baskets during their debut appearance to visitors at a giant panda breeding centre in Ya’an, Sichuan province, China, on Aug. 21, 2015. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by China Stringer Network/Reuters)

Syrian migrants travel on a bus after arriving on a ferry carrying about 2,500 migrants from the Greek islands in the main port of Piraeus on Aug. 26, 2015, in Athens. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Milos Bicanski/Getty Images)
A rising sun illuminates the landscape on Aug. 22, 2015, near Bernbeuren, Germany. Visit Slate for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Karl-Josef Hildenbrand/AFP/Getty Images)

This week marks the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, which ultimately killed at least 1,836 people, forced 1.5 million people to evacuate the region, and did an estimated $81 billion of property damage. In 2005, Carlos Barria documented the destruction. This year, he returned to rephotograph modern day locations, holding prints of his images from 2005 to capture the differences to be seen 10 years later. (Photo by Carlos Barria/Reuters)

In 2010, while photographing a theater, Klaus Frahm snapped a color Polaroid of the audience from backstage. On his way home he took a look at the frame and had a surge of inspiration looking at the deep red seats that seemed to pop out of the image. It proved to be a catalyst for a series, “The Fourth Wall: Stages,” which he has been working on for nearly five years. Above, Cuvillé-Theater, Munich, 2013.

Comedians are upset about @TheFatJewish and internet joke stealing. But does anyone *else* care? Few of his millions of fans seem to mind that many of his jokes come directly — copy / pasted verbatim — from other comedians.  Nor do the followers of known joke-aggreators like @9GAG @FuckJerry.tv @KanyeDoingThings @JetStreamofBullshit and @beigecardigan. Many are giving lazy efforts at sourcing — at best.

Are you a fan of any of those accounts? Would it bother you to know that many of the jokes you see on a daily basis are often stolen directly from the work of others? (Photo illustration by @l_l_w. Photo of Kanye West by Craig Barritt)

Markus Brunetti studies each church, cathedral, and cloister he photographs closely before taking hundreds, and sometimes thousands, of frames during similar light and weather conditions. He shoots everything from a street-level perspective without cranes or drones and then, along with Betty Schoener, his partner in work and life, he mounts and reconstructs the facades “in our own intensive process of composition” that allows for the viewer to appreciate all of the intricate details of the structures.  The buildings are often under construction, so if he needs to reshoot any piece of the puzzle, he might have to wait years until scaffolding is removed before completing the work. Left: Köln Hohe Domkirche St. Petrus, 2008–14. Right: Chartres, Cathédrale Notre-Dame, 2012–15. (Courtesy @yossimilo Gallery) #MarkusBrunetti

Mega-successful tennis star Serena Williams may be dating a former Canadian teen actor, TMZ reports. Williams is said to have been spotting canoodling with the handsome "boy toy," Aubrey Graham, after winning a tennis tournament in Cincinnati. Williams' dalliance with a less accomplished partner, to many, may be reminiscent of elite London human rights lawyer Amal Alamuddin's infamous 2014 marriage to an American actor who never graduated from college. Read more on The Slatest. (Photo illustration by @fotobomba, photos by WireImage) @serenawilliams @champagnepapi

Indonesian men in teams of four try to climb to the top of a greased pole called a panjat pinang in order to get to the prizes tied to the top on Aug. 17, 2015, in Jakarta, Indonesia. Cities and villages across Indonesia celebrated the country’s 70th anniversary with traditional games, music, and flag-raising ceremonies. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Ed Wray/Getty Images)

“I like to have different experiences,” said photographer Harry Gruyaert. “Not being stuck to the same thing, being interested in different things in your life, to have as many experiences as possible, if you only have one love affair in your life, it’s a big tight; experiences influence and change me, and I ask what can I do with that, it’s about being stimulated, talking about life, and moving.” A collection of his work will be published by @thamesandhudson this fall. Above, Flanders region, Belgium. Province of Brabant, 1988.

“I try to get to what is the strongest,” said Harry Gruyaert, about his photography. “What tells a story by itself and not as part of a series; more like tableaux, single paintings.” A collection of his work will be published by @thamesandhudson this fall. Above, Ostende, Belgium, Thermal palace, 1988. @magnumphotos

A dinghy overcrowded with Syrian refugees drifts in the Aegean Sea between Turkey and Greece after its motor broke down off the Greek island of Kos, on Aug. 11, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Yannis Behrakis/Reuters)

A flower grower, known as a silletero, rests on the ground during the annual flower parade in Medellín, Colombia, on Aug. 9, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Fredy Builes/Reuters)

Metronome magazine was the preeminent publication for reviews, features, and show listings of the jazz era. Closed in 1961, its archives are now the basis for for a traveling exhibition made possible by @limitedruns. Above, Billie Holiday performs at the Downbeat club in February 1947 in New York City. (Photo courtesy of Limited Runs, photographer unknown)

The Lagoon Nebula is a vast, 100-light-year-wide star factory. It’s a huge cloud of gas and dust, and inside of it stars are born out of that material. It’s very active, and has been for a long time; embedded in it is a cluster of over a thousand stars that are only a few million years old. Star forming nebulae are typically a mess, with massive stars blasting out radiation and fierce winds of subatomic particles. This slams into the material floating between the stars, lighting it up and sculpting it into fantastic and weird shapes. (Photo from the Hubble Space Telescope by NASA, ESA, J. Trauger JPL) @thebadastronomer

A fisherman walks on a port as Typhoon Soudelor approaches in Fujian Province, China, on Aug. 7, 2015. Taiwan evacuated hundreds of people from their homes on Friday as the strongest typhoon to threaten the island in two years churned toward it and was expected to make landfall today. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photo. (Photo by China Stringer Network via Reuters)

Satellite DSCOVR is four times farther away from the Earth than the Moon is, so it’s well outside the Moon’s orbit. Twice a year or so everything lines up just right, and Earth, Moon, and DSCOVR form a perfect line. Above: the magic moment showing the far side of the moon as it crosses between the DSCOVR spacecraft and the Earth, at one million miles away, as captured by the satellite’s Earth Polychromatic Imaging Camera, EPIC! (Photo by NASA via Getty Images) @thebadastronomer

Today, Japan marks the 70th anniversary of the first atomic bomb that was dropped by the United States on Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. At least 70,000 people were killed instantly and thousands more died as a result of the residual radiation. In 2007, the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum opened its archive to photographer Ishiuchi Miyako, and since then she’s photographed hundreds of artifacts that survived the blast impact. Above, a skirt from “Here and Now: Atomic Bomb Artifacts, ひろしま/Hiroshima 1945/2007—."

Krishna's Butter Ball, a giant boulder in Mahabalipuram, India, appears to be frozen in its roll down the hill it sits on, and no one is quite sure why. The boulder is likely a glacial erratic that got stranded in a serendipitous position on the hill, but local legend has another version of the story. According to Hindu mythology, when the great god Krishna was just a baby, he was fond of stealing butter. Following this tradition, the big orange stone has been likened to a giant dollop of purloined butter that the god dropped. (Photo by Dey.sandip/Wikimedia Comms) @atlasobscura

A child rides on the shoulders of a man as he walks through a field of sunflowers during a three-day sunflower festival in the town of Nogi, Japan, in Tochigi prefecture, some 70 kilometers north of Tokyo on July 26, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Kazuhiro Nogi/AFP/Getty Images)

Plants grow on houses in the abandoned fishing village of Houtouwan on the island of Shengshan on July 26, 2015. Just a handful of people still live in a village on Shengshan Island, which is east of Shanghai, that was once home to more than 2,000 fishermen. Every day hundreds of tourists visit Houtouwan, making their way on narrow footpaths past tumbledown houses overtaken by vegetation. The remote village, on one of more than 400 islands in the Shengsi archipelago, was abandoned in the early 1990s as first wealthy residents then others moved away, aiming to flee problems with education and food delivery. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Damir Sagolj/Reuters)

“I think the basic truth is that kids are truly at ease [at Burning Man]. In some sense, it’s as though we, the adults, get to spend a week remembering how to be like them—to meet them in that imaginative space in which they naturally exist,” said Zipporah Lomax, who has attended Burning Man every year since 2000 and is now publishing a book of her portraits of the event’s youngest participants. Above: Jessica and Jonakai, Burning Man 2014. @zipporahlomax

The moon rises over people gathered on Glastonbury Tor, in Somerset, England, a day prior to the blue moon of July 31. ICYMI, a Blue Moon is the second of two full moons appearing in the same calendar month. The last time this happened was in 2012 and there isn't due another until 2018. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Matt Cardy/Getty Images)

Coyotes have been around NYC for longer than most people realize. In 1995, the first coyote sighting was reported in the five boroughs. Today, coyotes live throughout much of the Bronx, and have been sighted in Manhattan as well as Queens. For example, in March of this year, a coyote was discovered on the rooftop of a bar in Queens, running back and forth before vanishing. "He didn’t pay his tab," joked the bar owner. (Photo by Caitlin Cahill)

A street poem by Scottish artist Robert Montgomery, who often posts typographic messages over existing billboards in a protest against advertising. This piece, along with works from 80 artists from around the world, is part of Street Messages, an illustrated survey of the literary side of today’s global street art movement by German photographer and author Nicholas Ganz.
(Photo courtesy of Dokument Press) @robertmontgomeryghost @dokumentpress #theeyeslate

Today's weather on the East Coast was captured eloquently with a tweet by the Capital Weather Gang—"It's gross out." For several years, on sweltering days like this, Ruben Natal-San Miguel has been photographing the pure (and mildly illegal) joy of dancing in the street with the spray from an open fire hydrant. Above, Bronx, 7/20/15 4:30-8:30 PM, 95 degrees.

“If it’s true that the top 1 percent owns half of global wealth, it’s hard to argue that we’re all in this together. So I wanted to borrow organizing principles [from Edward Steichen’s photography exhibit at the MoMA, “Family of Man” that was first shown in 1955] but critique it by only including photos taken from the world of wealth.” @myleslittle on “One Percent: Privilege in a Time of Global Inequality,” a collection of images curated from the many agencies he encounters through his day job as a Photo Editor at @time. Above, Varvara in Her Home Cinema, Moscow, 2010. (Photo by Anna Skladmann)

A policewoman tries to stop a member of the All India Mahila Congress, the women’s wing of the Congress Party, who was trying to cross over a barricade during a protest against Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi on July 21, 2015. Modi is under pressure from the opposition to fire his foreign minister and a state leader amid claims they gave favors to a sports tycoon living in London who faces allegations of tax evasion. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Adnan Abidi/Reuters)

Cyclists hang on to the back of a truck outside Bujumbura, Burundi, on July 19, 2015. Each day scores of cyclists make the 45-kilometer (28-mile) downhill journey at breakneck speed from Bugarama to sell bananas, often hanging from the back of trucks for the return uphill trip. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Mike Hutchings/Reuters)

The Soyuz TMA-17M spacecraft carrying the International Space Station crew of Kjell Lindgren of the U.S., Oleg Kononenko of Russia, and Kimiya Yui of Japan blasts off from the launch pad  in Kazakhstan on July 23, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Shamil Zhumatov/Reuters)

Last month Google introduced a trippy program called DeepDream, which early adopters have used to generate psychedelic variations of everything from Hieronymus Bosch to porn. By taking these objects and subjecting them to analysis using a “neural net”—or what’s known as “deep learning”—DeepDream produces images bubbling with eyes, birds, blinding contours, and other things that look like they belong on the cover of a King Crimson album. It’s dazzling and surreal—further evidence of Salvador Dalí’s discovery that eyeballs can only improve art—but also creepy. It suggests some sort of creativity in the mind of the machine doing the processing, and some sort of dreamer at the heart of the dream. Above, DeepDream's interpretation of Prince William; Kate, duchess of Cambridge; and Prince George. (Photo by Government House NZ via Getty Images transformed by @dreamscopeapp)

The Skylodge Adventure Suites has been housing intrepid travelers since 2013 in hanging bedrooms suspended on a rock face 1,312 feet above the Sacred Valley in Cusco, Peru. (Photo courtesy of Natura Vive) #theeyeslate

“It's much easier than it used to be to take decent images, photos that are in focus and properly exposed even in tricky positions. But photographers can build a narrative into a picture to show what's going on, to show competing or contradictory images within a single frame or across a series of pictures. That's a real skill and it takes many years to develop it. That's what amateurs lack,” said Julian Stallabrass, curator of an exhibition of @magnumphotos photographers' wartime photojournalism at the National Civil War Centre in the UK. Above: A Qaddafi supporter holds a portrait of the Libyan leader as fireworks go up in the background on a soccer field in a suburb of Zawiyah where government minders took a group of foreign journalists to attend a staged celebration, Libya, 2011. (Photo by Moises Saman/Magnum Photos)

When @kylecassidy got a call Friday afternoon from his longtime collaborator Kate McKinnon to see if he wanted to photograph the scientists behind NASA’s New Horizons space probe, he didn’t think twice before he agreed.

Clockwise from top left:

Dr. Brian May, Scientific Collaborator. “Pure art and pure science are the pinnacles of human endeavor. You can add love to that if you like. So much of what we do is for money, power, or advancement, but pure work is important because it stands apart from the things that we do for survival and extends the range of human consciousness.” Dr. Cathy Olkin, SWRI, Mission Co-I, Deputy Project Scientist. “Being a part of this team is an honor. I began working on New Horizons more than a decade ago during development of the spacecraft and instruments.” Dr. William B. McKinnon, Washington University, Mission Co-I, GGI Deputy Team Lead, Pluto Underground. “I do science because I want to know. I wanted to know what the planets are really like, and one by one, I found out.” Dr. Leslie Young, SWRI, Mission Co-I, Deputy Project Scientist & Pluto Encounter Lead. “Pluto promised us something wonderful, and it hasn't broken its promise. After this week, 'Planet or not?' is the least interesting question we could ask.” (Runs back, says, “Wait, just change my quote to: ‘SQUEE!!!’ ”)

Muslim worshipers pray at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on July 16, 2015, a day before the end of Ramadan. Visit Slate.com for more photos from this week from around the world. (Photo by AFP/Getty Images)

Monday night, the New Horizons spacecraft sent back the above picture of Pluto, the highest resolution color photo ever taken of the icy world. The color is real! The reddish hue is due to tholins, organic (carbon-based) molecules crated when methane, abundant on Pluto, is hit by ultraviolet light from the Sun. Other probes have gone this far, and farther, but none have gotten this close to an object in the remote and forbidding Kuiper Belt, the region of the solar system beyond Neptune containing billions of these small icy worlds. (Photo by NASA/JHUAPL/SwRI) @thebadastronomer

A Syrian refugee child, who has been living in Jordan with family for more than two years after fleeing the violence in their Syrian hometown of Idlib, poses in front of their family residence in Madaba city, near Amman, Jordan, on July 9, 2015. The number of Syrian refugees in neighboring countries has passed 4 million, the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR said on Thursday, adding that the total was on course to reach 4.27 million by the end of 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Muhammad Hamed/Reuters)

“I’m not nostalgic, but I find one of my major commitments to photography is its ability to provide a way of time travel so we can hold the past in the present.” – Janet Delaney, on her project documenting San Francisco's SOMA neighborhood, 30 years before it became the bastion of the tech economy that we know today. Above, Labyris Auto Repair, “Complete Car Care by Women,” 240 6th Street, 1982. #somasf @mack_books

The peloton rides in Seraing, Belgium, on July 7, 2015, at the start of Stage Four of the 2015 Tour de France, a 223.5-kilometer stage that ends in Cambrai, France. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Bryn Lennon/Getty Images)

Revelers run with Jandilla's fighting bulls along the Calle Estafeta during the second day of the San Fermin Running of the Bulls festival on July 7, 2015, in Pamplona, Spain. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Pablo Blazquez Dominguez/Getty Images)

In 2011, Barry Cox, who runs a tree relocating business, decided that his backyard was missing an old stone church like the ones he had studied and admired on travels to Europe. So he decided to unite his passion for ecclesiastical architecture with his skills as a landscaper to create a church made out of living trees. Cox constructed an iron frame, around which he used cut-leaf alder trees for the roof canopy and copper sheen for the walls, as well as camellia black tie, Norway maple, andpyramidal white cedar, training their branches around the iron structure.

Mennonite colonies in Santa Cruz, Bolivia strictly eschew modern technologies and social comforts, including photography. "I tended to spend a couple of days with each family not taking pictures, or taking them from far away, and then I would see how they responded and then get closer and closer," said photographer Jordi Ruiz Cirera. In the months that he lived with different communities, he came to find individuality amidst the outward uniformity, and a sense of strength in this mutual commitment to live for work and for family. @jordiruizc

“A lot of photographers take what they do so seriously that they overlook that the coin has two sides. There is also a happiness and positive side of life. We’re here for a reason and it’s not to suffer all the time. We’re here to find an uplift, a moral compass, and a beauty of the life we’re in that will lead us to a brightness and an understanding of life. That’s one of the great values of photography, especially street photography: It can show you the face of reality in a way that you realize that reality is far more than misery and unhappiness. ... Photography allows us to see the greater picture and the beauty of what we might be missing from our own perspective.” – Martin Elkort

Women watch fireworks as they swim in the Mediterranean Sea during the traditional San Juan’s (Saint John’s) night at La Misericordia Beach in Málaga, Spain, early on June 24, 2015. On San Juan's night, people burn objects they no longer want and make wishes as they jump through flames or into the sea. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Jon Nazca/Reuters)
#lovewins (lettering by @l_l_w)
A rainbow is seen over the Sydney Harbor Bridge on June 17, 2015, in Sydney. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Cameron Spencer/Getty Images)

"It’s easy to see why violent racists would single out black churches. They are major institutions for black Americans, vital sites for religious life and civic engagement. They’ve nourished activists, produced leaders, and provided a foundation for the long struggle against discrimination. They’ve been schools, training grounds, and safe havens... In other words, [the blackness of Emanuel AME Church in Charleston SC]—its great status in black history—made it a target for violence and hate." Visit Slate to read more from @jbouie. Above: Worshippers gather to pray down the street from the Emanuel AME Church following a shooting that killed nine people on June 17, 2015, in Charleston, South Carolina. (Photo by David Goldman/AP Images)

Laron syndrome is a rare form of dwarfism that also appeared to cause immunity to both diabetes and cancer. Nearly one-third of people known to have Laron live in the south of Ecuador, some of whom appear in the portrait series by Charlotte Schmitz, "Yo Soy Lo Que Soy" (I Am What I Am). Above, Maria José, 30, and her boyfriend, 20, in their apartment in Loja. @chardelotte
A container ship sails towards Colombo Harbour as the sun sets in Colombo, Sri Lanka, June 9, 2015. Visit Slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Dinuka Liyanawatte/Reuters)

In 1950 when Gisèle Freund, the only female founding member of the elite Magnum Photos collective, first befriended Frida Kahlo, the artist was in her most vulnerable, heavily medicated, and sometimes bed-ridden state, having undergone several surgeries, and requiring a wheelchair by the next year. But Freunde didn’t make photos about pain. Instead, she focused on the magic and grace that shone through the darkness.

In 2012, unable to contend with her consumer debt, photographer Brittany Powell filed for bankruptcy. With the desire to decided to open up a new communication around the stigmas associated with debt, she has been taking portraits of other people carrying a significant amount of debt, most often from student loans. Above, Michele Manis, housekeeper/artist in $35,000 of debt. "I accumulated the last round of debt after paying off a large amount at 23 when I went back to college I acquired most of the debt. I also acquired much of the debt there the rest was mail order catalogs, debt and getting through in homeless times robbing Peter to pay Paul or so they say" [sic].

When Katarzyna Majak first started taking portraits of women in Poland who practiced witchcraft or were otherwise alternatively spiritual, finding participants was a challenge. "The power of the Catholic Church here has always been immense [here]," said Majak, and many of the women were afraid of "coming out." But once a woman named Maria Ela (bottom left) who is a healer, a visionary, and a respected witch, agreed to be photographed, the project quickly gained momentum. In total, Majak photographed 29 women. "It gave me lots of courage and a much wider perspective on what it means to be a woman," said Majak. "To be a witch means to be a woman of knowledge ... [my subjects are] more aware of the potential of this very part of themselves and decided to cherish it. Stand in the truth of who they are."

Two tornadoes emerging from the same parent thunderstorm is a rare occurrence, but capturing them both on film in addition to the supercell that spawned them is almost unheard of. "I've been trying to get a shot like this for a number of years," said weather photographer @kellydelay, who captured this incredible moment outside of Simla, Colorado on June 4. "There’s a few people around in my circles that have said that this is a shot of a lifetime, you may never see this again, and I believe them."

You might be unsure of exactly what you’re looking at when you first see the images in Roland Fischer’s series “Facades.” They could be tiles or fabric patterns or perhaps optical illusions. Unless you happen to recognize the patterns highlighted in the photographs, your only clue that you’re looking at the facades of buildings is a straightforward title that lists the building name and city where it stands. Clockwise from top left, Cecil Street, Singapore, 2002; Highschool, Utrecht, 2013; Suntory, Tokyo, 2014; Nikko, Paris, 2002.

Batsheva Dance Company dancers during a full dress rehearsal before their new show Last Work in Tel Aviv, Israel, on June 1, 2015. Visit Slate.com to see more from the week in photos. (Photo by Ronen Zvulun/Reuters)

“I took this picture in May 2008. Having spent the previous few years on a series of embeds with the American armed forces, I had only seen the war through the narrow lens of a foreign military, almost devoid of any connection to the local population. I felt more like I was in America than in Afghanistan or Iraq. This trip was the first time I went un-embedded. I traveled around the north with Dost Mohammed Khairy, a disabled Afghan living in Phoenix who had gone back to Afghanistan to get married. This picture was taken on his wedding night, his bride Fahima posing with his nieces. Because of that trip, I began to realize the deep limitations of my perspective. Where Afghans had been shadowy and collective figures to me before, they had finally become individuals that I could start to see. I felt ashamed that my scope had been so narrow, and began to change the way I work.” —Peter van Agtmael, on an image that #ChangedEverything in his life and career. Visit Behold to see more from other members of @magnumphotos.

"People all have a human side to them," said Eli Reed, the first black member of Magnum Photos, who joined in 1988. "I grew up in the housing project and most of the guys that I played stickball with were the tough guys... they had been tagged as the troublemakers. But every single one of my friends had a gentle side." From African refugees to poor Americans, much of his work has focuses on disenfranchised or marginalized groups. "I’ll always have concern for people who are at the low end of the pole according to the rest of society." Above, "Lost Boys" of Sudan, Kalma Refugee Camp, Northern Kenya, 2001. @magnumphotos @elireedmagnum
#gabfestweather from NYC. (Photo by @l_l_w)

Sonny Liston landed on canvas below Muhammad Ali’s feet on May 25, 1965, and Neil Leifer snapped a photo. At that moment, 50 years ago, two legends were born, but one was broken. One feels so bad for Liston. So many of us give up on things, parts of our lives, throwing in the towel on whole swaths of our past, recognizing too late, if we recognize at all, that the subconscious compromises we don’t even realize we’re making are the most decimating compromises of all. But at least we’re not forever immortalized in the midst of our most capitulating posture. 
Visit slate.com to read more from 'How Things Break' by Dave Mondy.

A Rohingya Muslim man looks on as he stands on a boat near a jetty at a refugee camp outside Sittwe, Myanmar, on May 22, 2015. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Ye Aung Thu/AFP/Getty Images)

Same-sex love has gotten the green-light in Vienna, as the city has installed special traffic light filters depicting male-male, female-female, and opposite-sex couples in place of the typical stick figures. The charming initiative was originally undertaken as part of preparations for a cluster of tolerance-themed events taking place in the city, including the Life Ball (a major European HIV/AIDS fundraiser) and the upcoming Eurovision song contest. Described by city traffic official Maria Vassilakou as having already achieved “cult status,” the traffic lights, which were placed at 47 different intersections, have now been approved to remain in place indefinitely after June, when they were scheduled to be taken down. (Photo by Dieter Nagl/AFP/Getty Images)

A bird flies over a blossoming poppy field against the backdrop of a city and the Tien Shan mountains on the outskirts of Almaty, Kazakhstan, on May 14, 2015. Visit slate.com for more from this week in photos. (Photo by Shamil Zhumatov/Reuters)

"What you call love was invented by guys like me, to sell nylons. You’re born alone and you die alone and this world just drops a bunch of rules on top of you to make you forget those facts. But I never forget. I’m living like there’s no tomorrow, because there isn’t one." Seven seasons, two marriages, and more than 3,000 tomorrows later, it’s still unclear whether Don was pitching more to Rachel or to himself. In many ways, these are the ultimate questions Sunday’s finale will answer: Does Don believe in love? Does the world around him? #madmenfinale

"People couldn’t separate themselves from [the Apartheid's legacy]," said South African photographer Roger Ballen about his portrait series, Outland, originally published in 2001 and re-released again this spring. "Most writers are able to find it easier to talk about political and social issues rather than aesthetic ones. … It’s all about projection, all about defense mechanisms coming out. ... When I look back on it, my purpose was to try to deal with the absurdity of human existence." @phaidonsnaps

On Monday, New York City’s Fox affiliate ran a segment about the record-breaking auction of a painting by Pablo Picasso. Like much of his art, the work featured some female nudity, albeit of the Cubist variety—censored by the station. Inspired by the station’s expert blurring, Slate decided to see what other masterpieces of art history would look like if censored by a similarly overzealous local news channel. Above, Liberty Leading the People by Eugène Delacroix, 1830.

"Normally, if you ask me how to do astrophotography, among other things I’ll say you need to have access to dark skies. But that’s not always true. Look no further for proof of this than Terry Robinson. He lives in Melbourne Australia, under what he calls "a great light done". Despite that, with much care and practice, he has taken jaw-dropping photos of deep-sky objects. That spectacular photo is using two filters: One that picks out the light from warm hydrogen (colored red in the photo), and another that sees light from rarefied oxygen (blue in the photo; he did a combination of both to mimic green). The total exposure time overall was 43,500 seconds: more than 12 hours!" @thebadastronomer

Los Angeles–based designer Emily McDowell was diagnosed with Stage 3 Hodgkin’s lymphoma at age 24, enduring nine months of chemo and radiation before going into remission. "The most difficult part of my illness wasn’t losing my hair, or being erroneously called ‘sir’ by Starbucks baristas, or sickness from chemo," said McDowell. "It was the loneliness and isolation I felt when many of my close friends and family members disappeared because they didn’t know what to say, or said the absolute wrong thing without realizing it." The 38-year-old designer has been cancer-free ever since. But the emotional impact of the experience lingered, inspiring her to design a newly launched series of Empathy Cards—emotionally direct greeting cards that say the things she wanted to hear when she was ill. @emilymcdowell_

When Carolyn L. Sherer started photographing lesbians and their families in Birmingham, Alabama, in 2011 many chose not to show their faces. They were scared, they said, of losing their jobs or being discriminated against in other ways. But Sherer, who is a lesbian, was determined to make members of her community in Birmingham seem less invisible, in part because she hoped that letting others see them would help them become fully recognized and protected citizens. In some respects, have improved since this project titled “Living in Limbo” began, but in March, the Alabama Supreme Court upheld the gay marriage ban there, and the state still doesn’t have any laws on the books addressing discrimination or hate crimes against LGBTQ citizens.

Today marks the 45th anniversary of the Kent State shootings. "It’s a difficult story to tell," said Carole Barbato, a communication studies professor at Kent State University who was a junior at KSU when the shootings occurred. "Don’t get me wrong. Nobody at Kent State in 1970 wanted to be martyrs; nobody who came to that rally on May 4 would have ever expected for those guns to have been loaded. My students (today) think it’s stupid; there are guns, of course they are loaded. When you see the guardsmen standing there with their bayonets, their rifles, we didn’t think they would be loaded! Why would you have loaded weapons on a college campus? There was nothing that warranted that." Above, Mary Ann Vecchio screams as she kneels over the body of Jeffrey Miller during an anti-war demonstration at Kent State University, Ohio, May 4, 1970. Four students were killed when Ohio National Guard troops fired at some 600 anti-war demonstrators. (Photo by John Filo/Getty Images)

George Carrano, a Bronx native and retired MTA employee, created the Developing Lives program, a series of photography workshops that, over the years, put single-use Kodak film cameras in the hands of hundreds of NYCHA residents—mostly pre-teens and seniors—and encouraged them to photograph their everyday lives. Said Carrano, "We believe that negative portrayal of the housing projects accounts, at least in part, for the government rolling back funding since the 1970s. Our hope was that if the narrative of life in the projects could be turned back to the residents who live there, it could make an impact on government support and funding." Above: Photo by Jared Wellington. "We roam around this spontaneous block sticking together as brothers. Yet we are cousins."

"[Jerome Liebling] had a really charismatic and unique way about him," said his daughter Rachel, who helped to edit an exhibition of his never before seen photos left after his death in 2011. "The Rolleiflex became part of his body and it was almost like choreography the way he would approach his subjects. I know this not only because I remember being out with him, but you can also see it in the images. He would walk right up to people, and they were intrigued by him... He really connected with people; they look at him and they’re both equally checking one another out." Above, Butterfly Boy, New York City, 1949. (© JeromeLieblingPhotography, courtesy @stevenkashergallery)

A protestor wearing a gas mask rides past a line of police in front of a burning CVS store in Baltimore, Maryland, April 27, 2015. Violent demonstrations took place following the funeral of Freddie Gray, a 25 year old man who died as a result of injuries sustained while in police custody. (Photo by Jim Bourg)

Nepalese novice Buddhist monks offer prayers for the victims of an earthquake in Nepal that claimed the lives of more than 2,500 people and injured around 5,800.  A total of 22 climbers have been confirmed dead in what is Everest’s worst disaster, and Nepal has been hit by at least 34 aftershocks since Saturday’s massive quake. (Photo by STRDEL/AFP/Getty Images)

"In order to make something substantial, you have to go in there and observe, you have to get into it," said Jacqueline Hassink, photographer who completed a 10-year series with a focus on the Zen Buddhist temples and gardens found in Kyoto, Japan in 2014. "Not everyone can do it but I think it’s very complex, it’s not so easy, you need to study and understand things and you need time to do it well." Hassink said once the series was finished and she showed it to some of the monks, many of them commented that they had never seen their world portrayed in such an authentic manner. She said creating a cohesive body of work was paramount to the amount of time she spent in Kyoto.

Above, Jikkō-in 1. Northeast Kyoto. June 29, 2004 (9:30 a.m.–10:30 a.m.) @jacquelinehassink @benrubi_gallery

On Wednesday afternoon residents of southern Chile were caught off guard when the Calbuco volcano, dormant for the last 42 years, unexpectedly sprang to life. “Less than 24 hours [before], the volcano was completely on the lowest alert level,” said Erik Klemetti, a geoscientist at Denison University. “Volcanoes will sometimes throw you a curveball.” Photo of the eruption as seen from the city of Puerto Montt, April 22, 2015. (Photo by Rafael Arenas/STR/Reuters)

@thebadastronomer explains how @amandaleighcurtis's photo of a quadruple rainbow is real. "Double rainbows are fairly common (despite the meme). I’ve seen dozens of them; they’re caused when the sunlight hitting raindrops is particularly bright. [In this photo] the angle of the weirder, more vertical bows is what gives it away. If the light forming rainbows reflects off a body of water (say, a lake, pond, or even standing water on a road) you get another set of rainbows cast at a different angle ... it proves, once again, that you should heed my advice: Always look up. You never know what’s going on above your head." 🌈

Since he began photographing marijuana in 2009, Erik Christiansen has come to appreciate the subtle differences amongst hundreds of strains of marijuana, now compiled in a new book, Green: A Field Guide to Marijuana. Above, LA Confidential. "It’s easy to grow, looks amazing, has a classic old-school flavor, and affects your body with a deep relaxation." @nugshots @chroniclebooks

"Since we, the American public, are now facing the prospect of the most drawn-out, mind-numbingly protracted presidential runup in history, the least the candidates can do is to provide us with some fashtainment. Candidates: Ditch the Dacron! Let vanity fair!" Jeb Bush in Moncler Gamme Blue by Thom Browne, Rand Paul in Comme des Garçons, as part of the 2016 campaign trail imagined by @simon_doonan. (Photo illustration by @l_l_w, photos by Getty Images) #campaignfashionreport #thombrowne #commedesgarcons

A couple wearing masks kiss along a street during a sandstorm in Beijing on April 15, 2015. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by China Daily via Reuters) ht #magrittethelovers 😷❤️😷

An aerial view of flower fields is seen near the Keukenhof park, also known as the Garden of Europe, in Lisse, Netherlands, on April 15, 2015. Keukenhof, which employs some 30 gardeners, is considered to be the world’s largest flower garden, displaying millions of flowers every year. Visit slate.com for more from the week in photos. (Photo by Yves Herman/Reuters)

Happy Record Store Day! On this occasion, a throwback to a Behold feature from 2014, 'Dust & Grooves: Adventures in Record Collecting' by Eilon Paz. "It's just me and the camera and that's it," said Paz. "It's like two friends hanging out listening to records and then I shoot some photos. It builds a very intimate moment between me and my subjects. When they talk about music they lose all their inhibitions. They just really enjoy it." Above, Eothen Alapatt, better known as Egon, a vinyl record collector from Los Angeles. @eilonpaz #recordstoreday

Cats make great company for artists, suggests artist and journalist Alison Nastasi, because they possess some of the same defining characters traits as their owners. "There’s this idea that artists are aloof and independent and maybe rebellious so I think there’s definitely traits shared between artists and their cats in that way. A lot of that is a stereotype but I think a lot of it is true," she said. Natasi's book, Artists and Their Cats, charts the special relationship between more than 50 of the art world’s greatest luminaries and their furry friends. 
Clockwise from top left, Edward Gorey (📷 Eleanor Garvey), Salvador Dalí (📷 Roger Higgins/Library of Congress), Agnès Varda (📷 Didier Doussin), and Georgia O’Keeffe (📷 John Candelario/Palace of the Governors Photo Archives)

Yaakov and Mariya Shapirshetyn, married July 6, 1949. Yaakov: What is the secret to love? A secret is a secret, and I don’t reveal my secrets. 
Excerpt from Lauren Fleishman's 'The Lovers', a six year long project photographing couples who have been together for over half a century. @laurenfleishman @schilt_publishing

Yevgeniy and Lyubov Kissin, married on June 29, 1941. Yevgeniy: We met at a dancing party. It was in January 1938. My friend invited me to the party. He said there would be a lot of beautiful young girls. Another cadet with high boots had approached her, but she didn’t like high boots and so she said no to him. I was the second one to approach her. I had a different uniform, but I’m still not sure if it was my uniform or my face that attracted her to me.

Excerpt from Lauren Fleishman's 'The Lovers', a six year long project photographing couples who have been together for over half a century. @laurenfleishman @schilt_publishing

"A lot of [beefcake photography] was a secret history, tucked away in shoeboxes or under beds. The photographers were all fascinating characters of varying shapes and sizes who were brave enough to risk for their art by breaking the law. The models were doing it for a couple of bucks and they were either spotted at the gym or pulled from the streets so there isn’t much documentation about them." – Petra Mason, editor of 100% Rare All Natural Beefcake. Above, Brooklyn Boys, New York, early 1960s. (Photo by Danny Fitzgerald and Les Demi Dieux, courtesy of BigKugels Photographic) @rizzolibooks
Cherry blossoms bloom on the U.S. Capitol grounds in Washington on April 8, 2015. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Paul J. Richards/AFP/Getty Images)
A total lunar eclipse between cherry blossoms in Shiraishi, Japan, on April 4, 2015. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Kyodo via Reuters)

"[Dogs] definitely take on their owners’ traits, much the way a child would with their parents," said Will Robson-Scott. "I’m a believer that there aren’t that many badly behaved dogs, there are just badly behaved owners." He collaborated with his childhood friend, Ollie Grove, to create In Dogs We Trust, "A survey of modern day dog ownership." Above, Martin Parr and Ruby, Bristol, England.

'Biophilia' is a spectacular aesthetic taxonomy of the natural world created by photographer and designer Christopher Marley. "I think the unity [of all organisms and natural elements] is really an important part of the Biophilia theory," said Marley. "It’s really because we are a part of nature that we find beauty in it, and not the other way around." @abramsbooks

Looking at the gorgeous, dramatic images of Baroque churches in Cyril Porchet’s series, "Seduction," you might mistake the photographer for a religious man. But Porchet is more interested in the power the photos represent than the religious ideology. He sees the often-deceiving art of photography as part of the same game of message making and spin as the opulent colors, grand domes, and theatrical lighting of the churches. Above, Alte Kapelle, Regensburg, Germany.

A boy waits for a Buddhist ordination ceremony to start during the Poy Sang Long Festival on April 1, 2015, in Mae Hong Son, Thailand. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Taylor Weidman/Getty Images)

A man walks through a cloud of red-hued dust in Dubai, April 2, 2015. To see more photos of the sandstorm that traversed the Arabian Peninsula this week, visit Slate.com (Photo by Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters) #sandstorm #dubai

Swedish car company Volvo is helping nighttime cyclists defend themselves against cars with Life Paint, a spray-on reflective paint developed by Grey London in collaboration with reflective paint makers Albedo100 that uses special adhesives that are invisible in daylight but light up after dark in the glare of automobile headlights. Life Paint can be applied to any fabric and washes off without damage to the material. It is currently being market tested in the U.K., with an international rollout if the idea proves popular. @greyldn #reflective

Slinkachu has been creating and photographing miniatures in cities around the world since 2006. For inspiration, he turns to old landscape and baroque paintings and tropes from films such as The Sound of Music, which tend to represent the “nature we imagine we want, rather than the reality.”

“I first noticed [how New York dogs wait outside for their owners] when I would visit friends on the Lower East side,” said Erik Carter, of his project, Leashes & Longing. “Especially during brunch. I would notice people coming up to the dogs to give them water or to sit beside them; sometimes you see them sitting beside their owners sharing and eggs benedict.” @erik_carter

New York City Fire Department personnel work to extinguish a fire after an explosion on 2nd Avenue in Manhattan's East Village on March 26, 2015. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Andrew Burton/Getty Images)

Annie Collinge photographed women and their doll doppelgangers, for her project, Five Inches of Limbo. She combed eBay and junk stores looking for dolls, and the streets of New York looking for the perfect doubles. "I just thought it would be an amusing idea to get something that’s based on reality and try to turn it back into reality and see what happened," said Collinge. @anniecollinge

"To be welcomed in by strangers and have that warmth, it really changed my perspective on humanity. You assume people have a distance but in that moment all of these barriers dissolved and I was welcomed in and shown such openness. It was amazing." Jenny Lewis on her project photographing new mothers with their children, One Day Young. Above, Xanthe and Louie. @__JennyLewis__

Before photographer Jenny Lewis had her first child, the only stories she heard about giving birth were terrifying. “It was like ‘Oh, God, how am I going to get through this?’ ” she recalled. But Lewis’ experience turned out to be a positive one, so she decided to begin a project that captured the emotions of new motherhood, 24 hours in. Above, Hazel and Rudy. @__JennyLewis__

"The digital revolution has sped up, flattened out, and depersonalized communication, stripping away the necessity of charm. When rapid-fire emails have replaced lengthy imploring epistles, who needs charm? When sexts precede conversation, who needs charm? ... My charm offensive will prove that charm can be shekeltastic. Charm can be modern. Charm can be naughty. Charm is a feel-good thang, and the charming shall inherit the Earth." From the introduction to @simon_doonan's Charm Offensive on Slate.com.

A Balinese man kicks up burning coconut husks while celebrating Mesabatan Api, a ritual symbolically purifying the universe and human body through fire, on March 20, 2015, in Gianyar, Bali, Indonesia. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Agung Parameswara/Getty Images)

A father and son on a makeshift boat paddle through a garbage-filled river as they collect plastic bottles that they can sell in Manila, Philippines, on March 19, 2015. They earn $3 a day for this work. See more from the Week in Photos on Slate.com. (Photo by Noel Celis/AFP/Getty Images)
Last Tuesday was the best chance to see the northern lights overhead in a decade. Photo by Anders Jildén, part of a gallery of aurora borealis highlights on Slate.com.

For Jess Dugan's portrait series, Every Breath We Drew, she chose subjects who redefine the idea of masculinity. In doing so, she was able to put herself into a variety of situations in which she could measure her own sense of self. "It made me think a lot about authoring your own identity and this slippery moment where there is a time when someone else sees something in you that is reflective of who you are but it’s not necessarily visible to the larger world," she said. "I was interested with this world: What does it really mean to be seen by someone not just on the surface with all of these external identifiers but really on a more intimate level and how can that exchange go back and forth." Above, Laurel, 2014.

This ridiculously beautiful photograph is by Rogelio Bernal Andreo, a master's master of astrophotography. It’s so complex, so detailed, so deep and crowded that it took @thebadastronomer a moment to find the actual stars of Orion in it! The large red flower-like cloud to the left is the Lambda Orionis nebula, a star-forming cloud centered on the supergiant star Lamba Orionis. The red glow (and in the loop as well) is from hydrogen gas. It’s probably about 130 light years in size. Orion is on its side here, with orange supergiant Betelgeuse to the lower left, and the iconic belt in the center, pointing upper left to lower right.

"It’s not just about showing multicultural families," said photographer Michele Crowe of her project, The Universal Family. "It’s about all different types of families all over the world and saying we’re all coming from the same place; we’re all at home laughing and loving and I want everybody to see that." Above, Bryan and Mia, Levittown, New York. Spring, 2011. @michele_crowe

The Soyuz TMA-14M capsule with International Space Station crew members Barry Wilmore of the U.S., and Alexander Samokutyaev and Elena Serova of Russia, is seen above clouds as it descends beneath a parachute just before landing southeast of Zhezkazgan in central Kazakhstan, on March 12, 2015. See more from the Week in Photos on slate.com. (Photo by NASA via Reuters)

A lighting technician puts the finishing touches on Temple, a structure designed by David Best and assembled by Catholic and Protestant workers along with his team, in Derry-Londonderry, Northern Ireland, on March 13, 2015. For one week, starting March 14, the structure will be open to the public to visit and write memorials, concluding in a bonfire of the Temple. To see more from the Week in Photos visit slate.com (Photo by Cathal McNaughton/@Reuters)

A visitor carries an American flag at the Viola Liuzzo memorial on the side of U.S. Highway 80 on March 7, 2015, in Lowndes County, Alabama. Viola Liuzzo was a civil rights activist who was shot and killed by the Ku Klux Klan while shuttling fellow activists to the Montgomery airport during the 1965 Selma to Montgomery march. To see more from the Week In Photos, visit slate.com. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

"Porn stars are photographed everyday from every angle imaginable," remarked photographer Roger Kisby. "What I wondered was, ‘How do you shoot them in a way that’s not been done before?’ ... They have a certain way they’re used to being shot. They’d have a kind of porn look that they do—the sexy eyes and pouty lips. You’ll still see that in some of the pictures I’ve shown. But I tried to steer them away from that." Above, photo of @therealjamesdeen. @rogerkisby

Born in the Bronx, Lawrence Schwartzwald has an almost Woody Allen–esque love for New York: He’s a lifelong walker who enjoys people-watching and takes breaks to read books in cafés. In the early 1970s, Schwartzwald picked up a copy of Andre Kertesz’s On Reading and felt inspired looking at the black-and-white candid images of people reading around the world and wanted to do something similar -- but it wouldn’t be until many years later that Schwarzwald would pick up a camera. Above, Bookseller (“Crack Salesman"), Columbus Avenue, July 12, 2001.

Hal Fischer’s 1977 book, Gay Semiotics, is a tongue-in-cheek look at gay life in San Francisco’s Castro neighborhood. “I was exposing something and I was celebrating it by using text and a certain way of photographing in a very deliberately artificial way to disarm it, to not make it threating,” Fischer said. “This isn’t Mapplethorpe doing S&M work, this is a 180 degree opposite.” @cherryandmartin

"When I normally take portraits, the person’s connection and their eyes are the most important part of the photograph, how they connect to the camera. So with the honey their eyes are shut so the physicality of being covered in honey and the physical experience replaces the emotion of the eyes," said Blake Little, in discussing his portrait series, Preservation. "People react differently to the experience and that creates the emotion of the picture." Above, Chandra, reclining, 2014. @blakelittlephoto

Smoke and lava spew from the Villarrica volcano, as seen from Pucón, to the south of Santiago, Chile, on March 3, 2015. The volcano went quiet on Tuesday after an eruption that sent a plume of ash and lava high into the sky in the early hours put Chile on high alert. (Photo by Claudia Bucarey/Reuters)

A Kenya Wildlife Service officer stands near a burning pile of 15 tons of elephant ivory seized at Nairobi National Park on March 3, 2015. Fifteen tons is the largest amount of contraband ivory burned in Africa to date. The fire was lit by Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta to mark World Wildlife Day and African Environment Day. An average of 30,000 elephants are poached every year in Africa. (Photo by Carl de Souza/AFP/Getty Images)

Jean-Yves Lemoigne captured the grace of tennis with a strobe light and long exposure, each burst of light freezing the nuanced body language of player Louis Fabre. "The thing I enjoyed the most was how surprising and magical it was; in the dark studio when the light was flashing it was difficult to see anything. But after each shot, when I turned my head to look at the computer, something completely different from what I just saw appeared on the screen." @jeanyveslemoigne #chronophotography

“There is something universal about being a teenage girl," said photographer Rania Matar. "Being a girl, being a mother, being a woman. I include both [Lebanese and American] cultures, not to compare them but to show the universality about it. All my projects are on some level autobiographical; I’m photographing what I’m going through in my life through other people." Above,  from her project, 'Ordinary Lives' Soraya and Tala, Yarze, Lebanon, 2014. @raniamatar

"Even long-term residents [of Istanbul] cannot believe that my photos are of the city they live in," wrote architect and photographer Yener Torun. "One of my first motives to start this project was to show the less-known, colorful and modern side of the city. This is an attempt to change the one-dimensional perception of Istanbul. There are a million different worlds in this mega city and I try to discover the most colorful and graphic ones and display them." @cimkedi #istanbul

Here’s something you probably didn't expect to see today: a weasel riding on the back of a flying woodpecker! This incredible image, by Martin Le-May, was taken in Hornchurch Country Park in East London, capturing the weasel in the middle of a laudably courageous but ultimately poorly thought out attack. Le-May said the pair got about 10 feet off the ground before landing again, where the bird managed to free itself of the weasel and fly off, both creatures apparently unharmed.

"[The East Village] was so full of life, of people I saw, many of whom are no longer with us and here I am, this middle aged guy," said photographer Ken Schles, who captured moments otherwise forgotten amidst chaos and crime in the 80s in NYC. "I wasn’t looking to do a nostalgic look back at this time because I don’t feel I’m nostalgic about those people and those times, but what I was making was something about what does it mean to be alive and present in a place at a specific time ... especially knowing I had all of these losses." Above, Suzie Streetwalker at Limelight, 1983. @kenschles @howardgreenberggallery

Leonard Nimoy, actor, writer, and director, came to the end of his long life on Friday at the age of 83. His role as Spock was the most important performance in Star Trek, and his shadow cast long over every following edition.  His reserved but mindful demeanor could not be fully explained as merely an alien bearing. It was dignity, one impossible to fake. “Don’t grieve … I have been, and always shall be, your friend.” #LLAP (Photo by Bertil Unger/Evening Standard/Getty Images)

Gracing the walls of Apple design guru Jony Ive, and many creatives alike, is a poster replete with profanity and insight, designed on a whim by Brian Buirge and Jason Bacher. The family friendly version above was a sarcastic response to criticism, "We made the poster such that you can still clearly tell what word is barely hidden from sight." #gfda @gooddsgnadvice

"Over four decades I listened for that music—in the mountains and on the tundra, on the shoulders of glaciers and the shore of the Arctic Ocean, and in the northern forest, learning the songs of the birds. ... There are moments when it sounds as if the waves will come crashing through the open windows, and carry us away. And then it falls to a whisper, and startles me awake. In these sudden still moments, I’m filled with an exquisite mixture of tranquility and dread. In the morning, I rise and do my best to write down the music that I heard in my dreams." Composer John Luther Adams describes his process to to discuss what climate change means for his work and how should artists engage with times of crisis, in his essay on Slate. (Photo by Thomas Shahan)

"Joan Rivers may have had a minor movie career, but she had a major Oscar career, and she should’ve been in the In Memoriam montage. She was one of the reasons that many of us even CARE about the awards—because we watched what happened after she disemboweled hapless celebrities on the red carpet. But, right now, somewhere, she’s writing a mean, bitter, hilarious joke about yet another club she wasn't let into." #slatebrowbeat #oscars2015 (Photo by Terry O'Neill/Getty Images)

Victoria Sambunaris has photographed grand landscapes over the course of 14 years of road trips around the United States. "I am curious about what I am seeing and find myself not only drawn to the magnificence of open land, dramatic vistas, and vast sky but rather to the recurring sprawl of massive development and junctures where nature meets culture unexpectedly and surprisingly sublimely." Above, Jacumba, California, 2010. @radius_books

This week commenced the year of the sheep, according to the lunar calendar and Chinese zodiac. Above, a woman takes a photo in front of a celebratory display in Hong Kong, Feb. 18, 2015. (Photo by Philippe Lopez/AFP/Getty Images)

Daisuke Takakura's 'Monodramatic' imagines a world that is filled with clones. We all have many different personalities, revealed by Takakura with the help of expressive models and the magic of post production.

A blast of cold air from Siberia shattered records in at least 60 cities this week. Above, snow covered ice is seen on the Hudson River in New York City on Feb. 17, 2015. (Photo by Timothy A. Clary/AFP/Getty Images)

"Watching all 60 films nominated for Oscars this year has reminded me that the films nominated for Best Picture are so not the whole story. The riskier, more daring, more idiosyncratic movies often can only eke out a nomination or two. It made me want to see a ranked list of every nominated movie made by one intrepid filmgoer who’d seen them all." Check out Joe Reid's ranking of all of the Oscar nominated films of 2015 on slate.com. #oscars2015

When you first enter Livraria Lello, one of Portugal's oldest bookstores, you might think that you've stumbled into a church. A Neo-Gothic façade hides a beautiful Art Nouveau interior, with a stained glass ceiling, carved wood paneling, and a breathtaking, curvaceous staircase that stretches across the store. #livrarialello #bookstore @atlasobscura (Photo by Michał Huniewicz)
Mount Sinabung ejects ash into the air in Karo regency in Indonesia’s North Sumatra province on Feb. 9, 2015. (Photo by Endro Lewa/Antara Photo Agency/Reuters)

Six months after she experienced a painful breakup, Laura Stevens came to terms with her heartbreak by staging portraits using her friends and a few strangers. “What was important for me was to try to represent the different phases of emotions one goes through when experiencing loss, as they can each feel so disparate and acute,” she wrote. “You long for the next stage to occur, because it means there is a change and the pain an confusion might sometime cease.” @misslaurastevens

When photographing Fashion Week, Dina Litovsky searches for the glances and gestures that reveal the real human experiences—boredom, lust, envy—that hide beneath the airbrushed glamour of the event. Above, J.Crew’s presentation at Lincoln Center, Fall 2014, New York City. @dina_litovsky @anastasiaphoto1 @jcrew
Syrian refugees who’ve fled ISIS play near their makeshift home in the suburbs of Ankara, Turkey, on Feb. 11, 2015. (Photo by Gokhan Balci/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images)

Gay visibility is at an all-time high in much of the West, but in West Africa, any tenuous gains that may have been achieved are quickly fading. Ernst Coppejans, a Dutch photographer, knows this; he has risked his safety and the safety of his subjects to make queer Africa visible. His award-winning photo-essay 'Dans Le Milieu' features LGBT people in African countries that prohibit homosexual acts, giving life and a human face to a community that we usually hear about only in the context of death, violence, and suppression. @ernstcoppejans #lgbt

New England is locked in to a weather pattern for the ages. Don’t expect it to change any time soon. Two more major storms are expected this week, one on Thursday to Friday and another potentially bigger one on Sunday, putting Boston on a pace for its snowiest winter ever. (Photo by Lane Turner/The Boston Globe via Getty Images)

Romina Ressia’s series, 'What Do You Hide?' is a vivid and colorful response to a human tendency to mask our emotions in order to try to blend in. "I think we all have light and darkness inside," said Ressia. "Human beings can be adorable and hateful and I love to show both sides... I found it interesting to make portraits of things that are considered negative in a colorful and beautiful way." @rominaressia
A flock of starlings prepare to land, and sleep, near the Arab Israeli city of Rahat, Feb. 2, 2015. (Photo by Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images)

"For a journalist like me," wrote Ryan Lenora Brown, "[the Ponte City apartmens] seemed almost too good to be true: a building that doubled as a neat metaphor for contemporary South Africa—a carefully wrought fortress of white privilege that had fallen into disrepair and violence before emerging, haltingly, into a more inclusive but far more uncertain version of itself... Yet, the building’s true intrigue comes in moments when its massive proportions seem to pull at the edges of the reality, allowing one to see Johannesburg as she never has before." Photo from the Ponte City project by Mikhael Subotzky in collaboration with Patrick Waterhouse @magnumphotos

"It’s the most amazing people-watching in the world," said photographer George Brainard of spectators at classic car events. "When you study this many people within a culture, you start to see patterns. You see the old guys with overalls, the biker types, the pinup girls, the rockabilly guys, the European tourists, the tough guy—all these different types. They’re all there." Above, Sandra and Paolo from Austin, Texas.  #dayofthedrags #lonestarroundup @geobrain

Photographer Andrew Fladeboe said the problem with taking pictures of herding dogs isn't the dogs, who are highly trained, but the handlers or owners who need encouragement. "It’s interesting, for example, convincing a farmer to walk to the top of a big hill, setting up my lights, lying in the mud or sheep shit, and trying to negotiate with the owner to get the dog to look a certain way," he wrote. "I must look like a crazy person to them. But often they end up enjoying the process and I somehow gain their respect." Above, Jazz of Stonewood Farm, German Shorthaired Pointer, 2014.

At first glance, Kurt Hörbst’s portraits may simply look like an exercise in Richard Avedon-esque minimalism. But learn more about his process, creating high-resolution life-size images of subjects uniformly lying on a white background, and it becomes clear Hörbst almost has more in common with a taxonomer than a fashion photographer. "I’m interested in people and how they look and I’m very interested in comparing bodies ... Every human body gets digitized under the same conditions." Above, Anna and Julia, from Vienna_Scans, 2012.

"You often hear that everyone’s a photographer these days, which is true and wonderful and I love it. But what sets these photographers apart is all the time they spend not taking pictures," said Bryan Formhals, who along with Stephen McLaren published 'Photographers’ Sketchbooks' last year. "They spend so much time editing and thinking and writing and researching. It’s not just about pressing the button on the camera." Above, a page by Jim Goldberg, 'Candy'. @bryan_formhals @thamesandhudson #jimgoldberg

Throughout her life, photographer Carrie Schneider has been keenly aware of the lack of women represented in the canonization of art and literature. "Representing women friends, many of them artists, writers, and musicians reading women authors sought to undermine this dominant cultural narrative," she wrote, of her series Reading Women. "There is something rare about the depth of concentration that can be experienced while reading, and these are the moments I’m after: where the woman becomes immersed in her text, and begins to lose awareness of the camera, and a pose." Above, Bianca reading Sylvia Plath (Ariel, 1965). @carrie_schneider

The United States flag is appearing in small ways in the clothing worn by Cubans, amidst the suddenly warming relations between the two countries. Gydis Ricardo Vargas, left, and Yaime Machado Garcia wear scarves in the Vedado district of Havana, Jan. 26, 2015. (Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

Vulnicura, Bjork's latest album set for a spring release but dropped this month after tracks leaked on the internet, is an unexpected gift that breaks with the hermeticism of her more conceptual projects and transcends its own melodrama, coming through its vale of tears reawakened, damp and shiny. "When we’re broken we are whole," she concludes, "and when we’re whole we’re broken." Can she get an amen? Read more from Carl Wilson's review on slate.com (Photo illustration by Slate, photo by Jamie McCarthy/Wireimage via Getty Images) #Bjork

"It’s hard to describe what it’s like to turn up at a location," said Beth Moon, who has photographed ancient trees, some as old as as old as 4,000 years, for over a decade. "Since a lot of anticipation goes into the journey, excitement is inevitable. The size usually overwhelms me, there is a lot to take in. I don’t even consider taking out equipment until I am in a state of mind to concentrate and be able to work a camera."

Chances are you probably wouldn’t have thought to break any of the laws Olivia Locher portrays in her ongoing series "I Fought the Law," which examines the weird, outdated, and unbelievable laws found in all 50 states. Many of them would be extremely difficult to enforce, yet, based on her research, Locher said that many of them are still on the books. Be warned: in Ohio, it’s illegal to disrobe in front of a man’s portrait. @olivialocher

Clare Benson grew up on Drummond Island, Michigan, the daughter of a hunter with generations of hunters before him. Though she learned to shoot a bow and arrow as a child, her father never took her hunting. Armed with a camera, "The Shepherd’s Daughter," consisting of photos of her father and siblings engaged in real and imagined hunting scenarios, as well as self-portraits in similar truth-blurring situations, is her way of discovering a tradition that, in many ways, is her heritage, but, in other ways, still remains a mystery.

The south Iranian city of Shiraz is home to three neighboring mosques with jaw-dropping architecture. Shah Cheragh, above, was first built during the 12th century, its interior lined with millions of tiny, glittering mirror shards. (Photo by David Holt) @atlasobscura

"Life [Magazine] stories were told through the framework of the white middle-class American family. When stories did appear about African-American subjects, they were either about celebrities or athletes or people in very dire straits. [Gordon] Parks set out with this project to really counter those stereotypes," said Karen Haas, the Lane Curator of Photographs at MFA Boston. Parks’ goal, Haas said, was to bring to Life a better sense of the range of black experience in America, and to show black families in "a very dignified and proud place in life," yet, the photos from this project were never published in the pages of Life Magazine. Above: St. Louis, 1950. Photograph courtesy Museum of Fine Arts, Boston and the Gordon Parks Foundation @mfaboston #gordonparks

Just north of the small Italian town of Bomarzo is a quiet park where sunlight filters through the canopies of trees onto the “Mouth of Hell.” Parco dei Mostri, or the Park of the Monsters emerged from the tormented mind of 16th-century Italian prince Pier Francesco Orsini. The prince endured a brutal war, saw his friend killed, was held for ransom for years, and returned home only to have his beloved wife die. Seeking a way to express his grief, Orsini hired architect Pirro Ligorio to create a park that would shock and frighten its visitors. (Photo by Pavlo Boyko/Creative Commons) #parcodeimostri @atlasobscura

"After having a child I no longer have time to have winter depression. My daily life has been far more compressed," said Pauline Drasbæek, a subject of Arko Datto's series of portraits of people who suffer from seasonal affective disorder. "We discussed how we could make a portrait based on how they were feeling when affected," said Datto. "Eventually I came up with the portrait that best encapsulated what their situation was ... It’s a cyclical struggle for a lot of people."

"It’s interesting to think about what it’s like to be a kid," said photographer Anna Ream. She photographs children holding their most prized possessions, for her series, Comfort Objects. "[I'm] fascinated by [their] link to parenting, and to motherhood in particular," says Ream.
"I find it interesting that to photograph something that is so important to [children] changes the dynamic and it’s a way to honor and respect them." Above, Graydon and Doggy, 2013. @anna_ream

This week, the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival announced the lineup for its 2015 festival. Here’s what the lineup poster looks like when you show only the female-fronted acts. #brochella (Illustration by @deephunk, article by @sheisarebel)

Residents return to their homes following the hostage situation at Port de Vincennes on Jan. 9, 2015 in Paris, France. At least four hostages are reported to have been killed, as well as the two gunmen suspected in the attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo earlier this week. (Photo by Dan Kitwood/Getty Images)

Albert Vaughn was the neighborhood guardian, the older teenager who would play ball with the younger kids and try to keep them safe from trouble. About 50 of his friends and family members gathered to remember "Lil Al" on the block where he was killed. Englewood, Chicago, 2008. "I wanted to show how people lived in spaces and how they communicated with the world surrounding them. I wanted to show resilience, love, joy and what happens to people when violence destroys their communities," said photographer Carlos Javier Ortiz. @carlosjavierortiz @bronxdocumentarycenter

A man standing in Place de la République holds a placard reading "I am Charlie" as he attends a vigil to pay tribute to the victims of a shooting by gunmen at the Paris office of Charlie Hebdo, Jan. 7, 2015. #jesuischarlie (Photo by Youssef Boudlal/Reuters)

Gearing up for the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope this April, NASA released an immensely detailed and seriously jaw-dropping image of M16, the famous star-forming region nicknamed the Pillars of Creation. @thebadastronomer

Landschaftspark Duisburg-Nord (the Landscape Park of North Duisburg) in western Germany is a grand recreation venue with a past life as a blast furnace complex for a local ironworks company, opened in 1991. At night, buildings glow in a rainbow of neon hues as part of a light sculpture created by British artist, Jonathan Park. (Photo by Thomas Wensing/Flickr Creative Commons) @atlasobscura #landschaftsparkduisburg

“Kate came up with that [title],” said Roger Steffens, of @thefamilyacid, a presentation of his photo archive digitized by his son Devon and curated by his daughter Kate, “I don’t know exactly why; maybe because my wife and I met on an acid trip in a pygmy forest in Mendocino under a total eclipse of the moon on Memorial Day in 1975 ... It really is a group effort. The whole family is involved in it, which just thrills me.” Above, The Redwood Alien, December 1983.

In the ’50s through the mid-1960s still photographs were one of the primary vehicles connecting movie fans to the stars they loved. Contact sheets from the era offer a more intimate look at silver screen celebrities "than a still photograph that's been edited, cropped, and airbrushed could do alone," said Karina Longworth, author of 'Hollywood Frame by Frame'. (Photos from Breakfast at Tiffany’s by Paramount/The Kobal Collection/Howell Conant) @papress #audreyhepburn

Tonight marks the point where the Earth is closest to the Sun all year: perihelion. At that time, the center of the Earth will be 147,096,204 kilometers (91,401,343 miles) from the center of the Sun. On average, that distance is 149,597,871 km, so we’re roughly 2.5 million km closer tonight than on average. (Photo of the Sun as it appeared just a few hours before perihelion 2015, as seen by NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory) @thebadastronomer #perihelion

Every day, an old married couple watches the sunset from a tranquil coastal spot at Ise in Japan’s southern Mie prefecture. Connected to one another by a rope woven from rice straw, husband and wife sit quietly as the sun dips from view. These two rocks are known collectively as Meoto Iwa (the wedded rocks), representing Izanagi and Izanami, the married deities who created Japan, and 'kami', spirits believed to inhabit people, places, and objects in the natural world, according to Shinto mythology. (Photo courtesy Tawashi2006/Wikimedia Commons) #meotoiwa @atlasobscura

A girl from the minority Yazidi sect, fleeing the violence in the Iraqi town of Sinjar, rests at the Iraqi-Syrian border crossing in Fishkhabour in the Dohuk province of Iraq on Aug. 13, 2014. See more photos from the year in review on slate.com. (Photo by Youssef Boudlal/Reuters)

"[Images from the International Space Station] show our planet from a perspective the vast majority of us will never see for ourselves. Simply seeing it from above shifts our preconceived notions of it, erases national borders, and shows global phenomena that tie our ideas of a divided Earth together." @thebadastronomer
Above, the view from the ISS looking down on Europe and Africa as it passes southeast down the Italy coast, across the Mediterranean, then across Egypt. (Photo by ESA/NASA)

Belgian photographer Maroesjka Lavigne was just 21 when she photographed her series, "Island," a melancholy and unique narrative amidst the snowy landscapes of Iceland. "Though they do justice to the country’s ample natural beauty, they’re way more odd and interesting than anything you’d find in a travel magazine," said Jordan G. Teicher of why it was one of his favorite photo shows of 2014. @maroesjkalavigne

Jen Davis: "Eleven Years" is a series of self-portraits, striking for their vulnerability, and Davis' talent for capturing beautiful compositions and light.
