"Looking at a life—anyone’s life—edited down to a small collection of images can be a profound experience for both the photographer and viewer," said @dmrtoast, of why it's one of his favorite photo shows of 2014. @jenedavisphoto

"With the rise of the digital age, there was an expectation that books were going away, but they’re not going away. They’ve sort of been reinvented," said Simon Brown, photographer of "The Weight of Knowledge," an ongoing series on the lives of old books. "They have a beauty, a permanency," said Brown. "They’re here to stay." #libraries @simonbrownphotography

“There is a real logic in the doing that is weirdly soothing, therapeutic,” said Clemens Habicht of his 1000 Colours puzzle that initially looks looks like a colorful blur. “As each piece clicks perfectly into place, just so, it's a little win, like a little pat on the back."

A diver recovers a Thompson sub-machine gun from the Calumet-Saganashkee Channel in a photo that ran in the Chicago Tribune on Saturday, August 6, 1949. The story that accompanied the photo reported the investigation of a holdup that led to the deaths of two guards in the course of a bank robbery. Three of the criminals were nabbed after a fourth named names; one of these identified the machine gun as the one used in the course of the crime. #crimescene #csi #1940s #chicago

Susan Middleton shows that marine invertebrates have personality by portraying them in the same way she would “a head of state or a celebrity or my best friend ... I want to photograph gestures that are natural expressions of who they are. I try to create environments where they can reveal themselves. I don’t approach them with preconceptions, but I do see things sometimes that I associate with our own gestures, such as the Stubby Squid.  It appears laid back and relaxed and comfortable in its own skin.”

“Part of the reason [candid celebrity photos in the 70s] were so cool is because there wasn’t an enormous proliferation of images from back then,” said photographer Brad Elterman. “Having a camera was rare. When I was hanging out with the Ramones, they were like ‘Cool, Brad has a camera.’ Everyone is so guarded today. The pictures I took and like to take are kind of a chill idea of life imitating art, the stuff that normal people do.” Above, Gene Simmons and Brooke Shields, Beverly Hills, 1978. @bradelterman

On Thursday, a thick fog filled Arizona’s Grand Canyon—a rare weather phenomenon called a “total cloud inversion.” The fog’s exceptional fluffiness turned the canyon into a mystical sea of clouds. (Photo by M. Quinn/National Park Service) #grandcanyon #cloudscape

In the southwest of Morocco, goats have no qualms about climbing trees in search of a feast. Drawn to the fruit of the argan, which ripens in June, they graze by the dozen standing together on the branches of a single tree. (Photo by Cuno de Boer/Flickr Creative Commons) #argan #goat

Michael Wolf has photographed the rooftop vistas of Paris, involving a scenic process from start to finish. “You climb up these old rickety ladders, past dead pigeons and trap doors. It was really like that movie Hugo with the boy trapped in the clock tower. That’s how I felt, it was magical, you pop open the last trap door and there you are except sometimes when the bells start ringing and you don’t expect it and you’re next to them!” #paris

For three consecutive years, Stacy Kranitz photographed and participated in nearly weeklong Battle of the Bulge re-enactments at Fort Indiantown Gap in Annville, Pennsylvania. Her interest in murky, imperfect characters and narratives shows in her photos, which reveal the joy, strangeness, and latent terror of events in which people spend quality time with their families, explore their passions, and get drunk—all while wielding guns and dressing as some of the 20th century’s greatest villains. Above, The Cossacks, 2009. @stacykranitz #blackandwhite #reenactment

“People benchmark their lives by different events,” said photographer Jonathan Sa'adah. “I was trying to bring people in by letting them benchmark against what happened to them. People want to talk about what happened and what they were going through during that period. They are coming to me and saying this is my experience at that time, your pictures from that period brought back memories.” Above, the West Side Drive in New York City, 1974, part of How Many Roads? — Sa'adah's collection of snapshots from the mid 70s. #oldnewyork #blackandwhite #1970s

Between 2006 and 2010, photographer Narayn Mahon visited Abkhazia, Northern Cyprus, Transnistria, Nagorno-Karabakh, and Somaliland, looking for a sense of “identity and isolation” in places full of patriotism, yet excluded from the international community. Above, Farming, Carmanova, Transnistria, 2007.

“Nowadays, when information is accessible to almost every one, at all times, the sense of community offered by the library is vital, and will continue to be so as we become more tech-obsessed. The greatest challenge and opportunity for the architect, then, is creating a democratic and lasting social space for the public,” said Maeve Convery, editor of Reflections: Libraries. Above, Sir Duncan Rice Library, University of Aberdeen, U.K. (Photo by Adam Mørk) #libraries

“There was a lady on the sidewalk, a middle-aged white woman, and she was crying,” said Vic Oyedeji, 29, a recent transplant to the Bronx, who was deeply moved by the solidarity at protests following the grand jury decision not to charge a New York policeman in the choking death of Eric Garner. “I told her to come in. So she came in and we marched for about 20 minutes, and she said she’d never been a part of something like this in her lifetime.” He paused and surveyed the crowd. “Can you see this? This is not just black. This is not just Hispanic. This is every race together for a common cause. Obviously something has to change. I see our generation as a generation of change.” #ericgarner (Photo by Eduardo Munoz/Reuters)

The strange and terrible saga of the Hells Angels tendency towards violence and crime laid out by Hunter S. Thompson in 1966 is nowhere to be found in the Norwegian chapter, started in 1992. “It is a tight-knit brotherhood of guys who have known each other for a long time and who have sacrificed much to become who they are,” said photographer Marcel Leliënhof. Hells Angels MC Norway “is not a club of boy scouts, nor it is a club with a bunch of rabid lunatics with guns in one hand and drugs in the other.” #motorcyclejourneys
People take part in a protest against the grand jury decision on the death of Eric Garner in midtown Manhattan, Dec. 3, 2014. (Photo by Eric Thayer/Reuters) #ericgarner

You see them on street corners, at gas stations, at shopping malls. You see them at blowout sales and grand openings of all kinds; yet the dancing tube man was inspired by the graceful and free calypso dances of Trinidad and Tobago. Above, the premier of “Fly Guys” at the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. (Photo courtesy of Doron Gazit)

"I stared across at him and felt a familiar sick feeling. Perhaps this was only the beginning. The questions they would have. The questions they should be asking. The questions they would realize they had not been asking because they did not imagine they could, or because asking meant that they could no longer exist in their system." Read more from Suki Kim's excerpt on teaching to North Korean students on Slate. (Photo by Damir Sagolj/Reuters)

Located in a field in the Flemish province of Limburg, and accessible only by foot or bicycle, Reading Between the Lines is a church that appears either solid or half-dissolved, depending on the angle from which you view it. Installed in 2011, the structure consists of 100 layers of stacked steel plate interspersed with short columns to create the see through effect. No scheduled worship services take place inside, but visitors are welcome to enter the church and praise their deity of choice, whether it be God, art, or Carl Sagan. (Photo by 準建築人手札網站 Forgemind ArchiMedia/Flickr Creative Commons)

This image of Saturn, taken by the Cassini spacecraft in Aug. 14, 2014, shows nearly the entire face of the planet. That’s no small feat, given it’s 116,000 km girth. (Photo by NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute)

More than 1,000 demonstrators chant "Hands up, don't shoot!" in protest on the steps of the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C., a day after the Ferguson grand jury decision to not indict officer Darren Wilson in the Michael Brown case.
(Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

A car burns on the street in Ferguson, Missouri, as protesting erupts following the grand jury decision to not to indict officer Darren Wilson in the Aug. 9 shooting death of Michael Brown. (Photo by Jim Young/Reuters) #ferguson

Peter Byrne loved watching professional wrestling on television as a kid. He found boxing too violent, but, with wrestling, “you had pure theater, and a great deal of fun. There were guys bashing the hell out of each other, but you kind of knew nobody really got hurt.” In 1988, he photographed the last glory days of professional wrestling in northern England, before the sport was pulled from mainstream television, and embraced the glitz and glamour of American wrestling.
Turns out unruly goats and sheep make for some of the best portrait subjects. Kevin Horan found this out while photographing his neighbor’s livestock for what would become his series “Chattel.”

Dan Eckstein was traveling through Rajasthan after a 2011 wedding in Goa when he first noticed the colorful, personalized trucks that would later become the subject of his book, Horn Please. He returned to India in 2012 and 2013 for two three-week trips, and traveled more than 6,000 miles on highways across the country to photograph the amazing vehicles. "It was like a treasure hunt looking for the exact ones I wanted," Eckstein said. "It’s about finding the right trucks in the right light in the right space."

“I’m not declaring that this proposal is a suitable replacement for the USD as much as I’m suggesting that one could exist,” said Idaho-raised designer Travis Purrington of his redesign of US currency created while pursuing his Masters at the Basel School of Design in Switzerland. “I tried to tie the concept of learning, discovery, authorship, and accountability into the notes ... more than I worried if it looked too European or not ‘American’ enough.” @travispurrington #money

“Bookstores are holdouts from an earlier era,” said photographer Bryan David Griffith. “It’s not nostalgia necessarily, more of a study about the retail space, and how it might be a lot different 30 years from now.” Above: Weller Book Works, Salt Lake City, Utah. “I don’t like being called a retailer, and I don’t like being called a businessman. I prefer bookseller! In my mind, that’s saying you’re a purveyor of ideas and dreams and thinking,” said owner Tony Weller, shown reading defiantly on the floor. @wellerbookworks #independentbookstore #saltlakecity

Kathy Ryan, the director of photography at the New York Times Magazine, uses Instagram (@kathyryan1) as a diary of her life at the office. “Most of the credit goes to [architect Renzo Piano] himself and this building. The light is so extraordinary. I feel like I’m being handed the pictures.” #officeromance @aperture

Bradley L. Garrett has created the most comprehensive photographic account of subterranean London ever produced. “Many times, it is those things which you might not think are a productive use of time that spark the most exciting ideas,” said Garrett. “So I’d say just get out there, don’t take a plan or a map, don’t even have a goal necessarily. Just go and try new things. You don’t need permission for that and you need to stop waiting for it.” #urbanexploration

Vincent van Gogh's Starry Night comes to life on a bicycle path in Nuenen, Netherlands, where he lived from 1883 to 1885.  Daan Roosegaarde’s design studio created the installation with thousands of pebbles covered in a smart material that charge during daylight and seem to magically glow after dark to commence #vangogh2015, commemorating 125th anniversary of the painter’s death. (Image courtesy of Pim Hendriksen) #starrynight

November 16, 2014 marks the 40th anniversary of the Arecibo message, a binary string when displayed as a grid shows a pixelated summary of humanity. The target audience is Messier 13,  a globular cluster of stars located over 22,000 light years away. Even if the locals were to respond promptly to this message, we'd still have to wait at least 43,960 years for their reply. (Photo by ESA/Hubble and NASA)

One of seven ocean temples along the southwest coast of Bali, Pura Tanah Lot was built around the 16th century to honor the spirits of the sea. The temple is only accessible at low tide, when the water recedes enough to reveal a land bridge. (Photo by koyne/Flickr Creative Commons) #bali @atlasobscura

Elio Sorci was among the very first "paparazzo," a term coined by Federico Fellini for his film, La Dolce Vita, to describe a small band of press photographers who documented film production in Italy in the 1950s. Above, Brigitte Bardot filming in Fiesole, Tuscany, 1962. #paparazzo #ladolcevita @roadsgroup

When Martina Lindqvist's mother moved back to Finland, she realized just how little connection to her family roots she had. After growing up in Sweden and spending the last decade in England, she went to Finland to photograph 'Neighbours', a series of landscapes that spoke to her feelings of isolation and disconnect. "It felt very paradoxical that people would just leave their homes and go elsewhere while I was trying to sort of find my way back there," said Lindqvist. #finland

New York City was a "rich place" in the 1970s and 80s, said photographer Arlene Gottfried. "It was very diverse. It still is in some respects, you see a lot of different people, but it’s not the same." Above: Angel and Woman on Boardwalk, Brighton Beach, 1976.​ #35mm #brightonbeach

Every summer since 2009, Ariko Inaoka has photographed Erna and Hrefna, identical twins who live in Reykjavik, Iceland. “When I see them through my camera lens I see them as one. When I spend time with them without the camera I see them individually. They have different personalities.” @aarriikkoo #identicaltwins

Before William Karl Valentine followed his father's lead to a career in law enforcement, he spent two years amidst the frenzy of the crack epidemic taking pictures alongside on-duty cops in Pasadena. Above, Officer Hall at the Doo Dah Parade (annual spoof on the Rose Parade), 1985. #pasadena #35mm

Atop a volcanic neck in Myanmar, 2,417 feet above the sea, lies Taung Kalat, a Buddhist monastery populated by golden Buddhas, cheeky monkeys, and long-suffering spirits. Pilgrims climb 777 stairs barefoot and dodging monkey dung along the way to leave offerings at the colorful shrines at the summit. (Photo by Scott Edmunds/Creative Commons​) @atlasobscura

Washington D.C. is about to legalize marijuana, but will it be able to keep the cannabis industry out? Initiative 71 proposes that district residents will be able to grow a limited number of plants, possess a limited amount of the resulting cannabis, and give away—but not sell—whatever they don’t want to smoke themselves. (Illustration by Alex Eben Meyer) @alexebenmeyer #initiative71 #abrahamlincoln #doritos

Susan Copich channels Cindy Sherman to investigate her inner, darker thoughts about life as a mother and wife in her series, "Domestic Life." Her marriage “no longer felt shiny,” her kids seemed to have grown up overnight, and she felt “irrelevant” and middle aged. More importantly, she realized, she was absent from every family photo. "If you’ve met me, I have a very seemingly sunny disposition, but I have a whole interior world where at different times I’ve felt depression and angst... It’s been so fun to bring those feelings out and give them light."

Sheldon Nadelman got to know his customers better than most barkeeps in New York City. Aside from remembering the favorite drinks of regulars, they were his subjects for over a decade of portraiture. Duchess (1973) drank rum and coke, and is one of the thousands of patrons who he photographed at Terminal Bar until its closure in 1982.

Inspired by a dream, Steven Spazuk creates paintings with open flames, embellishing the fragile surface of the soot with handmade brushes. “Sometimes my work or my image is planned, but often I go with serendipity and spontaneity,” he says. “It interests me to see what I will discover.”​

This microscopic image of a rotifer, a tiny animal photographed using a technique known as differential interference contrast, 40x magnification, is this year's winner of the Nikon Small World photomicrography competition. (Photo by Rogelio Moreno Gill) #photomicrography

The Hooley Haunted Mansion in Texas was home to several strange deaths in the 1970s, when the mansion served as a bed and breakfast. From the series, '13: An American Horror Story'​ by Seph Lawless. @sephlawless​ #hauntedhouse #modern_ruins​

Seph Lawless goes boldly where few dare tread. His photographs of abandoned malls, factories, and homes reveals the eerie impact of globalization, and his series, '13: An American Horror Story', inspires fear outright. “I choose my projects based on I what believe the public wants," says Lawless. I think people want to be scared and they want to fear. As long as it’s in a controlled environment they find it comforting—even empowering. They safely want to watch from a distance on their smartphones as I go inside haunted houses." Above: The Nova House, Youngstown, Ohio. Benjamin Albright shot and killed his son by accident and then killed himself and his wife in 1958. The home has been vacant ever since and still has personal belongings inside. @sephlawless​ #hauntedhouse #modern_ruins

Walker Pickering's “Esprit de Corps,” combines his love of photography, nostalgia, and collective performance through documentation of marching bands. Above, Alex Judd, Drum Major, prepares the Longhorn Band for game day, University of Texas Longhorn Band, Austin, Texas. #longhorns

Fourteen seconds after launch tonight, the Orbital Sciences Corporation’s Antares unmanned rocket exploded. It’s not yet known why. Phil Plait (@thebadastronomer) to provide updates and more information on slate.com. (Photo by NASA TV via Reuters​) #antares

Halloween costumes don’t have to be tacky, expensive, or wasteful. Design-conscious minimalists with a penchant for user-friendly DIY might be intrigued by the inexpensive, handsomely designed, and subtly spooky geometric masks from designer Steve Wintercroft. @wintercroft​

Photographer Matt Black's life's work chronicles the plight of his native Central Valley. California is in the middle of its hottest and driest three years in recorded history. "Chances are it’s still going to be bad next year, but there’s also a chance it’s going to be severely bad," says Black. "Frankly, there’s not much hope. How do we accommodate this new reality? Farming is never going to go back, regardless of how much rain we get next year, to the way it was in the ’70s and ’80s. It’s a long-term era of scarcity." @mattblack_blackmatt #californiadrought​

Aunt Charlie’s Lounge is the last remaining gay bar in San Francisco's Tenderloin, an area once known for its LGBTQ nightlife and now with a crime rate 35 times higher than anywhere else in the city. Inspired by this place thriving on the commitment of its regular patrons, James Hosking photographed older performers, "[who] helped drag gain greater visibility simply by living their lives the way they wanted to." Above, Gustavo with a photo of himself as Donna Personna. @jameshosking #sanfrancisco #lgbtq​ #drag

Today is the last (partial) solar eclipse we'll see in the US until 2017​. Visit Slate's Bad Astronomy to find out how to observe the event safely, and when it's visible in your area. (Photomontage of partial solar event in May 2012 by Chris White)  #solareclipse

Sage Sohier's portraits of same sex couples and their families was ahead of its time in the 1980s, when headlines about gay people were overwhelmingly focused on AIDS and sexual promiscuity, and when many weren’t as publicly out as they are today. Said Sohier, “My ambition was to make pictures that challenged and moved people and that were interesting both visually and psychologically.”

Almost as quickly as Nevada became the fastest growing state in the US, its real estate market collapsed, leaving “dozens of cake-layered pads carved into the mountain without a single house.” Yet Michael Light's photographs are not meant to suggest the problems there are unique: Decadence and environmental destruction, he said, are, in a way, built in to the American ethos of expansionism.​

"I’m still not totally sure New York isn’t just a movie. Even after fifteen years of near nonstop New Yorking, it still seems more filmic than real. Nothing I do in New York feels completely believable unless it reminds me of something I’ve seen someone do in New York in a movie." —Elliott Kalan, Never Can Say Goodbye. (Photo by Ernst Haas/Getty Images) @saribotton​ @elliottkalan #ilovenyc

Anila Quayyum Agha​'s 2014 ArtPrize award winning sculpture, Intersections​, is patterned after the Alhambra fortress in Grenada, Spain​, a place of harmony for Islamic and Western history, culture and art. (Photo courtesy of the Grand Rapids Art Museum​) @anilaagha @gr_art_museum @artprize #alhambrapalace #intersections
Part art, part human, Nigel Grimmer​ creates irreverent drag self portraits costumed by kitsch canvases. Above, Nigel as J.H. Lynch​'s enigmatic Tina. #drag #kitsch #retro #jhlynch

In a new series called “Malkovich, Malkovich, Malkovich: Homage to Photographic Masters” by Sandro Miller, Malkovich plays the parts of man, woman, and child with an eerily unsettling plausibility in 32 wild portraits that celebrate great 20th-century photography.​ Above, an homage to Dorothea Lange’s 'Migrant Mother' ... starring John Malkovich. (Photo courtesy @edelmangallery​) #malkovich

Above: Fatemeh’s father is a librarian in a mosque.“People think I don't have freedom because my father is a cleric but it’s not true. He gave me permission to visit the national book fair with my friends when I was 15,” she said.​ While photographer @nafisemotlaq doesn’t think the relationship between fathers and daughters in Iran is too different from those in other countries, she was keen to capture it as a way to highlight the country’s “diversity of families, opinions, and classes of society.”​ #iran #fatherdaughter #portrait​

In the words of photographer Fred Lyon, “It would take another lifetime to explore the San Francisco I haven’t seen, and see in my imagination.  In the meanwhile, I’m chipping away at it.” #sanfrancisco #bayarea #sfhistory

"When I was a kid—this is true—I used to look up at the sky and fear that some day we’d explore everything and run out of things to discover. I was completely wrong. We’ll never run out of sky. Just look at it... All of the yellowish glow, all of it, is actually coming from stars.​" Phil Plait contemplates the estimated 200 billion stars in the Milky Way. (Image by Robert Gendler​) #astrophotography #milkyway

Runak Bapir Gherib, a 14-year-old from Shengal, makes her way down the Sinjar mountains after seven days. She is with her mother and sister (in the back) waiting for a car to drive them away. She took the gun from Shengal to protect her family. (Photo by Zmnako Ismael/Metrography, the first and only independent photo agency in Iraq, founded 2009) #roadsandkingdoms #metrography

The International Cloud Atlas is considering the inclusion of the first new cloud type since 1951, the undulatus asperatus. (Photo courtesy @z.zkt/Nik Gaffney/Flickr Creative Commons) @atlasobscura #clouds #undulatusasperatus #cloudappreciationsociety​

In Tokyo, technology and traditional culture exist shoulder-to-shoulder, described by photographer Matthew Pillsbury (@screenlives) as the place where “temples exist alongside the most popular Disney park and next to a giant Manga robot or a robot restaurant.”

@MSharkeyFoto​ takes portraits of a new generation of queer youth across the country and around the world. Photographing since 2006, Sharkey says, “I wish someone had given me the opportunity to have a voice as a young person, and I think these kids are really excited to have that opportunity. They want to be seen; they want to be heard; they don’t want to hide.”​

20 years since Itchy & Scratchy Land ran out of #Bort license plates, the “unmistakably Simpsonian” bit continues to unlock joy in the show's most discerning fans. If you believe this theory is bunk, visit the website of your state’s DMV and try to order a “Bort” vanity plate. Chances are some other Simpsons obsessive has beaten you to the punch line. (Photo by @l_l_w)

Photographer Michael Wolf’s “Architecture of Density” series focuses on the looming scale of high-rises in Hong Kong. “At some point I just took a photograph and I folded away the sky and the horizon until I just had the pure architecture,” he says.

Lydia Goldblatt is the daughter of her main subjects. In her series, 'Still Here' she reflects on her relationship to her parents, the fleetingness of time, life's many enigmas, and finds “maybe just [by] recognizing the questions for what they are, there is beauty in the process of simply looking for them.”
@willoremus explains the "pre-cation," ​the greatest job perk you've never heard of. (Photo courtesy Maciej Serafinowicz/Unsplash)​

In the words of photographer Robert Shults, the science conducted in 2009 at the Texas Petawatt Laser​ facility, capable of producing more power than the entire U.S. electrical grid​​ in a fraction of a second, was “indistinguishable from magic.”

"[They] were once the ultimate hipsters: notorious rogues and satyrs but also skeptics, seekers, and wits, none of them quite reducible to hippie stereotypes, a step ahead and a touch removed."—Carl Wilson muses on new albums by Robert Plant, Leonard Cohen (and Loudon Wainwright III). (Photo illustration by Slate. Photos by Neil Lupin/Redferns via Getty Images, Joel Saget/AFP/Getty Images)

'Bronx Boys' shows how neighborhood kids worked together to overcome systematic neglect during the 1980s. "When you are family, a place can still be dangerous at times but it is home. People protect you," said Stephen Shames, photographer of the series.
@swansburg tells the story of America's most pliable, pernicious, irrepressible myth: the self made man. (Illustration by @happymenocal)
#gabfestweather (Photo by @l_l_w)

As the first generation of Ukrainians born after the Chernobyl tragedy comes of age, a small subculture of them is now doing the unthinkable: defying government prohibitions and illegally entering the highly radioactive Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, or “Dead Zone”—for fun. “It’s a post-apocalyptic romance,” as one young man put it. (Photo by Chris Bairstow: The Babushkas of Chernobyl)
@tobycoulson's portrait series "Show" captures the unique humor and tenderness of competitive breeders posed with their animals.
Apricot fool with fresh peaches: A way to solve the problem of mediocre apricots with a little heat, sugar, and heavy cream. #dinnervschild (Photo by Mark Weinberg)
@asiakepka imagines the whirlwind romance and wanderlust of a middle-aged horse and squirrel in her series, “Horace and Agnes: A Love Story.”

still, there are those who see us 
hands reaching out, fists raising up, 
banners unfurling, megaphones booming
and we are canoes blocking coal ships
we are the radiance of solar villages
we are the fresh clean soil of farmer’s past
we are teenagers blooming petitions
we are families biking, recycling, reusing, 
engineers building, dreaming, designing,
artists painting, dancing, writing
and we are spreading the word
and there are thousands out on the street, 
marching hand in hand
chanting for change NOW
and they're marching for you
they're marching for us​

Excerpt from Kathy Jetnil-Kijiner's poem delivered yesterday at the UN Climate Summit.
(Photo by Mike Segar/Reuters​)

Located in the south Atlantic Ocean, 1,743 miles west of Cape Town, is Tristan da Cunha. Without an airport, and a minimum 7 day journey by boat, it is the most remote populated island in the world. @atlasobscura (Photo by Leo Genin/Creative Commons​)

Photographer @davidbenjaminsherry​ channels the large format landscapes of Adams and Weston, through a panicked neon monocolor inspired by climate change. Above, Winter Storm in Zion Canyon, Zion, Utah, 2013 -- more works from the series currently on view in NYC @danzigergallery @salon94​.
Stilt walkers awaiting the start of the #peoplesclimate march, 09.21.2014. (Photo by @l_l_w)
#peoplesclimate (Photo by @l_l_w)
Earlier this solar eventful month, astrophotographer Alan Friedman captured the beautiful patterns created by plasma and magnetic field lines dancing on the surface of the sun.

Harrel Williams Jr. is 2 years old. His parents both compete in the rodeo.​ Visit Behold for more of Forest McMullin's view into the all-black rodeo​ community and the overlooked history of the African-American cowboy.

One of the most amazing feats in the chess history just happened at a tournament in St. Louis, and Seth Stevenson was there to see it. Among the things he learned: "Professional chess requires a level of peak mental alertness that most of us achieve only in the throes of searing tooth pain." (Photo by Lennart Ootes)
Photographer Asako Shimizu traveled to the world’s largest salt flats to capture the endless horizon of the Earth, for the series, "On Her Skin".
Creativity, conspiracy theories, and delusions have one thing in common: apophenia.​ Article by @xwaldie, photo illustration by @l_l_w.
This photo of black ice blanketing Greenland is unsettling, but the implications for the climate are even worse. Jason Box shares his exclusive photos and research on "dark snow" on Slate.​

The bright comet Siding Spring is a favorite for astrophotographers and it's not hard to see why. Here, Marco Lorenzi captured it passing by one of the most beautiful objects in the sky: the globular cluster 47 Tuc.

Italian discotheques of the 80s and 90s were “large enough to contain the dreams of success, money, and fun of thousands of people." View more of the abandoned clubs photographed by Antonio La Grotta on Slate's Behold.
Twenty years after Ready to Die, the Notorious B.I.G. is STILL the greatest rapper who ever lived. (Photo illustration by @l_l_w, photo by Catherine McGann/Getty Images)
Under the light of a harvest supermoon, greet the sugar gliders of @traers 'Nocturne'.

"[Joan] Rivers’ real distinction is being one of the earliest female comedians to be relentlessly filthy, and also to talk in an unfiltered way about being a woman." (Photo by Joseph Del Valle/NBC/NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images)

120,000 Central Africans have fled the country in the last two years, according to the U.N., and 400,000 remain displaced within it. How did this happen in a country that had been peaceful for centuries? Read the sad, stunning story at Slate.com (Photo by Siegfried Modola/Reuters).
A stunning noctilucent (literally, “night shining”) cloud captured by @astrofotografen.

As summer comes to a close and the new school year begins, the landscape across the country begins to shift with the familiar scene of children waiting at the end of their driveways for the school bus to pick them up. See more from this series by @gregmillerfoto on our photo blog, Behold.

It's no surprise that Beyoncé identifies as a feminist. But the VMAs statement was next level—an unusually mainstream flaunting of feminist pride in our image-driven culture. And man did it feel good. Find more #VMA coverage at Slate.com (Photo by Michael Buckner/Getty Images)

From Nadav Kander, a Sunday picnic in Chongqing, China, one of the world's largest cities on the banks of the Yangtze. See more of his project capturing scenes from the nearly 4,000 mile course of the river on our photo blog Behold.
"To the degree that Instagram is fostering attention to the nature of the day, I think that’s a force for good." (Photo by @msjuliaturner) #gabfestweather

For the first time in four years, a Titan Arum flower at LA's Huntington Gardens will bloom, reaching around six feet in height and perfuming the air with the scent of rotting meat. @atlasobscura considers the #corpseflower on Slate.com. (Photo by Matt Blitz/Atlas Obscura)
Take a look inside the iconic taxis of Mumbai, as photographed by Dougie Wallace. To see more from his series, "Road Wallah," visit our photo blog Behold.

Feast your eyes on the glorious Ring Nebula! Phil Plait contemplates the mysterious shape of the dying star on Slate's Bad Astronomy. (Photo by NASA, ESA, and C. R. O'Dell (Vanderbilt University) and Robert Gendler)
